speech.para: With regard to the objects, as specified by Senator Forshaw in his amendments, the Tasmanian RFA would then not have subscribed to the establishment of a wood and paper industry council. Also, in subsection 2, under (iii), the Tasmanian RFA would then not have subscribed to `the maintenance of an extensive and permanent forest estate in Australia'. It simply applies to Tasmania.

talk.start.para: âI realise we have a number of amendments to go through, so I will not unnecessarily prolong the debate. I think it is appropriate to respond to Senator Forshaw's comments. Firstly, I am very pleased to see him reading my first speech. It was a very good speech, and I encourage all senators to quote it as often as possible.

speech.para: The points he made from the section he quoted were valid then and are valid now. There are two crucial points as to why what I said then was so correct. The first point is that the problem with the focus of the national competition policy when it was brought in was that it was pushed significantly, almost solely, on economic grounds without consideration for the human rights, environmental or social aspectsâI mentioned these in the speech that Senator Forshaw quotedâwhereas this amendment has been added to the objects that the ALP is proposing. It is a credit to the ALP that their amendments contain a range of matters other than economic principles. We are not putting forward competition policy in isolation and subverting the environment and everything beneath that, which was one of the major concerns the Democrats had with the national competition policy when it was first established.

The other important point, even leaving that aside for one minute, is the issue of consistency. Why should the timber industry be treated differently from other industries throughout Australia that have to be subjected to those principles? In a way, the comments of Senator Forshaw highlighted the ongoing problem that the Democrats have continually tried to emphasise over many years in relation to logging in our native forests, which is that it is not economic. It is able to be sustained only because of massive public subsidies which pay for the clear-felling.

What is really being said by the ALP is that they believe competition principles and economic measures should not be applied because, as Senator Forshaw said, this would close the industry overnight. I do not know whether it would or not, but if it did it would simply highlight how grossly uneconomic it actually is in the way it currently operates. Part of the original purpose of RFAs and one of the original aimsâapart from protecting the environmentâwas to enable an ongoing economically viable timber industry.

Despite the claims of Senator Forshaw and othersâand I am sure they will be repeated persistently throughout this debate, so I will just respond to them once now and try to refrain from countering them every time they are raisedâthe Democrats are not about trying to close down the timber industry overnight; we are about making it economically sustainable, and it is completely unsustainable economically if we continue to rely on logging and clear-felling our native forests. It is an economic question as well as an environmental question. The amount of public subsidy that has continued to be providedâand will continue to have to be providedâto the timber industry in relation to logging our native forests highlights why it is so crazy and why we need to move away from that.

In his comments, Senator Forshaw said that part of the RFA process is to make a `transition, we hope, which moves towards plantations.' We need to do more than hope; we have to ensure that we have as fast as possible a transition to plantations, because that is part of what it is all about. That is whyâas he also said in his speechâthe whole RFA process has a big question mark over it. The reason it has a big question mark over it is because, clearly, amongst a number of those that have been signed alreadyâand certainly in terms of what the timber board in my own state of Queensland is pressingâthey do not want to move into plantations; they want to maintain their hold on what are very fast dwindling areas of native forests in south-east Queensland, which goes against why we set down this path.

It is worth emphasising againâand I will not restate this every timeâthat the fact that the whole process has a huge question mark over it highlights why this bill should, ideally, be thrown out altogether and why that is the Democrats' preferred option. Despite the fact that we are trying to cooperate constructively in putting forward amendments and considering amendments that others are putting forward to make the bill less bad than it is, the Democrats' consideration of those amendments throughout this committee stage should not be mistaken for support in any way for this legislation.

I take the opportunity again to emphasise that, because the whole RFA process has a big question mark over itâas others have acknowledgedâwe should ideally be throwing this bill out altogether. Unfortunately, the ALP have made it clear that that is not going to occurâthey will vote for itâso we are forced to consider amending it. That is what the Democrat amendment is about. We will support the ALP's amendment as one way of creating some improvement, but we believe our amendments in relation to the timber industry having to meet the same economic requirements as other industries are important for consistency and transparency so that people can be aware of what subsidies are being provided. Senator Forshaw acknowledges that having to meet basic economic and competition requirements would have a negative impact on the industry and this highlights the economic inefficiency and the public subsidies that are already provided.

Whilst on face value it may perhaps appear that the amendment moved by Senator Greig is a mischievous amendmentâwhich Senator Forshaw suggestedâit is most definitely not. We believe that, because it has added to the very good objects that the ALP put forward and does not leave open the risks that are otherwise presented by competition policy and because it puts the industry into the same operation as other industries in Australia, it is one that should be supported. We are disappointed that the ALP are not willing to do that at this time.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that Democrat amendments Nos 1 and 7 on sheet 1514 be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move Democrat amendments Nos 2 through 6 on sheet 1514:

speech.para: (2) Amendment (R1), paragraph 2A(1)(b), omit "Wood and Paper Industry Council", substitute "RFA Forest Management Council".
(3) Amendment (R1), subparagraph 2A(2)(a)(ii), omit "includes", substitute "primarily includes conservation but also may include".
(4) Amendment (R1), subparagraph 2A(2)(a)(v), after "heritage", insert ", ecological".
(5) Amendment (R1), at the end of paragraph 2A(2)(a), add:
(viii) market based pricing, full cost recovery, a fair return on capital and an adequate return to the community for the use of a public resource;
(6) Amendment (R1), at the end of paragraph 2A(2)(b), add "whose primary purpose is conservation".

The Australian Labor Party are proposing to set up what is a very select industry council that deals with only one part of what forests are about. They have ignored tourism, environmental values, water catchment and recreational users. They are proposing to set up an industry council that the unions will acceptâa council that will be dedicated to finding more ways to sell woodchips or to put in pulpmills.

We have a series of amendments to the ALP amendments to try to make the council more balanced and to give the council responsibilities to look at ecologically sustainable forest management and so on. We will go through each of our changes in detail.

Democrat amendment (2) seeks to change the name of the council to better reflect what should be a rounded role. Democrat amendment (3) will include the notion of conservation as a primary goal of that council. Democrat amendment (4) seeks to put ecological values into the definition with those social values. Democrat amendment (5) is based around market pricing, on which we have spoken in relation to competition policy and so on. Finally, Democrat (6) would add the wording `whose primary purpose is conservation' to the ALP amendment and also add `relevant international agreements'. We want to specifically say that these are to be consistent with international agreements such as the biodiversity convention, migratory bird agreements, RAMSAR wetlands, and so on.

talk.start.para: âThe government maintains that the proposal, in respect of which we will be putting forward an amendment, still provides by far the best balance of a management body. Therefore, we will not be supporting the Democrat amendments.

âThe opposition will not be supporting these amendments. I think I covered nearly all the issues in earlier remarks when we debated Democrat amendments (1) and (7) with respect to the national competition principles agreement. Some of the issues, for instance amendment (5), relate to that and also my opening remarks with regard to the opposition's own amendment to insert an objects clause.

speech.para: Let me deal with a couple of things. Firstly, in regard to amendment (2), we do not support the proposal to change the name of the Wood and Paper Industry Council to the RFA forest management council. Indeed, as I outlined earlier, what we are seeking to do is establish a wood and paper industry council whose taskâas it was previously, and as acknowledged by the Senate committeeâis to look at issues; promote such things as value-adding and downstream processing; endeavour to make the forestry industry a more profitable and economic industry; and deal with issues such as how we can remove the trade imbalance that exists. That is the purpose of the Wood and Paper Industry Council. That is the way it was first established under the previous Labor government. We see it being established again by virtue of this legislation. It is not a body that would manage RFAs. It is not intended to be that. It was never intended to do that. The Democrats might wish that it took on that role, but it is not its role and function.

Obviously, part of its deliberations and work would clearly have regard to how RFAs are progressing in the context of, as we said, the whole process of enhancing and developing a sustainable, viable timber industry in this country into the future as we also balance out all those other considerations. So we cannot agree to that proposal. Later, when we come to the substantive amendments prepared by the opposition as to the structure of the Wood and Paper Industry Council, we will deal in more detail with it. But they are our reasons for opposing this amendment.

I have already addressed the other amendments, but I repeat: what we have proposed here is an objects clause which follows word for word the national goals of the national forest policy statement. We believe that we have covered all of the relevant issues there and that the wording is appropriate for an objects clause. We do not believe that the Democrat amendments really add anything more substantive to our proposal. Accordingly, we cannot support them.

talk.start.para: âOf course there is room for both but what we are going to get as a result of this committee deliberation is the usual one-sided outcome whereby the loggers get representation on a wood and paper industry council. If you look a little further down the bill, you will see that the government wants us to leave that to them to determine. They will bring in regulations at some time in the future and set it upâ
âSo we get a balance.

âSenator Troeth is saying, `So we get a balance,' but we have Senator Greig moving to give some balance here by bringing in the conservation interest, which the majority of Australians want to see, against the destructive woodchipping interests which predominate in this situation. Senator Troeth is going to oppose that. So much for her definition of balance. It is totally skewed against the interests of the majority of Australians, not least young Australians. That is going to be incorporated into a wood and paper industry council, which the government originally opposed anyway. It is a response to the Labor Party's efforts. Senator Murphy from Tasmania, who is not here today because he has other parliamentary business, has been very keen on this as a means of trying to get not just some balance but some review of the way in which the woodchip corporations have skewed the whole industryâshedding jobs and making it a profitable rip-off for them. No wonder the industry has such a bad name and no wonder the industry has left nobody feeling secure at all about the forests.

speech.para: No doubt, the wood and paper industry council which the government wants to set up is simply going to leave in the clutches of its friends in the woodchip industryâfriends who put hundreds of thousands of dollars a year into its electoral coffersâthe power and persuasion on a totally skewed council. It is not about balance at all. Senator Greig, on behalf of the Democrats, has moved to try to redress that imbalance by having heritage and environmental values brought into the terms of reference for this council and to ensure that environmental representatives are on the council. You would expect that, on its record, the Labor Party is not going to support that because it does want to see this council representing the lost interests of the workers. But the government is not even going to support that because it is a servant of a few big woodchip industries based in the capital cities, the executives of which have probably never been into a native forest in their lives.

talk.start.para: âWhy do you imagine you are the only one who ever has?

âSenator Troeth, I am going to ask youâyou dismissed my earlier questionâabout your knowledge of the Tasmanian forests. You have overstated, I think, that you have an acquaintance with the forests. I am going to ask you: which forests and where? We will see how great your acquaintance is and then we can debate the basis of that acquaintance and the impact that this legislation is going to have over the next 20 yearsâdevastation of those very forests.

speech.para: One thing which this does bring to mind is the term `ecologically sustainable', if Senator Greig does not mind me intervening to push the parliamentary secretary on this because it is pertinent to the good terms of reference he has brought forward. When I asked the parliamentary secretary what she meant by ecologically sustainable, she ducked that question. What I am really trying to get at is: is her definition of `ecologically sustainable' commensurate with `economically sustainable', the woodchippers' viewpoint? It is not good enough to say that you will have a sense of balance, as Senator Troeth might want to do. What we need to know is: does ecologically sustainable mean what it says? Does ecologically sustainable mean sustenance of the ecological systems of forests?

Senator Troeth said that I have no evidence that this was not being done in Tasmania. During the course of these committee discussions, I will give her ample evidence that ecological sustainability has been thrown out the window since the woodchip industry came to Tasmania, shedding 5,000 jobs, closing over 100 small sawmills, but reaching its cancerous impact into the forest with devastating effects. I will be interested to see how Senator Troeth defends her use of the term `ecologically sustainable'. It is going to be very helpful to this committee in what is going to be a rigorous analysis of the situation if Senator Troeth can give an exact definition of what ecologically sustainable means, and if she can say that that is commensurate or leaves room for her competing definition of `economically sustainable', the woodchippers preferred phrase. I have asked the Parliamentary Secretary a series of questions and I expect she is going to respond.

talk.start.para: âI do not know what more the government can do to illustrate the fact that we want an ecologically sustainable system by using the words in the bill as they are before me. I refer you to the general outline in the explanatory memorandum to the bill which says that:

speech.para: Completion of an RFA for a region will:
. ensure the long-term protection of environmental and heritage values through the establishment and management of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system; and
. provide the basis for an internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable native forest products industry.
Do those words mean anything to you as they are printed in the explanatory memorandum?

talk.start.para: âSenator Troeth, please address your remarks through the chair.

âCertainly, Madam Temporary Chairman. Through you, I suggest to Senator Brown that, as those words are printed in the explanatory memorandum, that is what they mean. I will not delay the committee with an outline of my life history, but I would like you to note that on many visits to Tasmania I have visited forest regions. Particularly, I have taken a trip from Triabunna through to Port Arthur, through the south-east region, where I did admire the beauty of the forests. But what Tasmania needs is jobs. That is what the successful completion of this legislation will do.

speech.para: Senator Brown talks about balance. You cannot possibly have balance without the proper consideration of all value systems. That requires the consideration and hopefully the implementation of economic value systems as well as environmental value systems. That is exactly what this legislation is designed to do.

talk.start.para: âI assure the chamber that I will deal with these crocodile tears about jobs later. The disease that produces those crocodile tears has now infected Senator Troeth. Since the regional forest agreement was signed by Prime Minister Howard the year before last, the promise of jobs has been totally thrown out the window. Over 400 jobs have been shed by the big woodchippers and the Tasmanian governmentâthe Bacon Labor governmentâfollowing on the heels of the Liberal government which signed the agreement. I will be asking Senator Troeth, case by case, how she explains the loss of these jobs since the regional forest agreement was signed, as it was put in place to substantiate jobs. Senator Troeth can get ready for that.

speech.para: This legislation is built on two lies. The first is that it was there for jobs. Patently it was not. Where RFAs have been signed, there has been a process of job sheddingâincluding cardholding members of the Forest Protection Society and the CFMEU. There have been no protests by Senator Troeth. She has not come down to object to it. I do not think she has been to see any woodchip corporation about that. It is easy to get up in here and abuse the hardship of the workers in the industry by touting jobs when, in fact, they are losing their jobs under the government's prescription.

I am not prepared to allow the other lie about maintaining environmental values to go unchallenged in this place. I would be letting down those peopleâand they are the majorityâwho can patently see that clear-fell logging in our forests is destructive. It is not ecologically sustainable. Those who use those terms in this process are not deceiving themselves, because they know what the process is: they are engaged in a fraudulent use of terminology against the interests of the majority of Australians.

Senator Troeth, if you look at the picture in my hand you will see the Tarkine Wilderness. Madam Temporary Chairman, if you look at the picture, you will see a hillside of the rainforest in the Tarkine Wilderness in Tasmania aflame, right across from one side to the other. In the centre is a little white streak which is a helicopter. That is dropping off hundreds of incendiaries, ping-pong balls full of incendiaries, which explode into fire when they hit the ground. What was there at the start of this decade was centuries of ancient, intact, sustained ecosystem. What has happened is that the forest has been cut down.

Under the direction of the woodchip industry, Forestry Tasmania has brought a helicopter across. It has dropped napalm-like incendiariesâthe whole mountainside is aflameâand that is to kill any remaining semblance of rainforest: the cotyledons, the little shoots that might come up, the root systems underneath. Any remnant wildlife is destroyed, including the birdlife. What is more, when this process was finished, 1080 poison was placed in that region, as is usual under this regional forest agreement process, to deliberately poison and kill any wildlife that wanders in from the remnant forest to that side to graze on the genetically manipulated eucalypts that are then put into that area for a quick buck further down the line by North Forest Pro ducts on this occasionâthe most voracious destroyer of forests in the Southern Hemisphere. I ask you, Senator Troeth: having viewed that picture, do you maintain that that is ecologically sustainable?

talk.start.para: âI will make a few further comments so that the Australian Democrats and other senators fully understand our opposition to their amendments, particularly amendments Nos 3 and 4. The objects clause that we have drafted follows, word for word, the national goals of the national forest policy statement. Amendment No. 3 seeks to insert some additional words into our amendment. Paragraph (2)(a)(ii) of our amendment reads:

speech.para: the management of Australia's forests in an ecologically sustainable manner for a range of uses that includes tourism, recreation and the production of non-wood products . . .

That is a straight translation of the words from the national forest policy statement. Whilst on the surface a reference to conservation may not be objectionable, the point we are making is that we believe the objects clause should follow the wording of the goals of the national forest policy statement. We do not think it should be tampered with by adding a word here or taking a word out somewhere else and replacing it with another reference that the Democrats or the chamber think might be more appropriate. This is a statement that was agreed to by the state and federal governments and we believe it is important to ensure accuracy in reflecting what was in that statement.

Similarly, in proposed amendment No. 4 moved by the Democrats, where they seek to insert the word `ecological' after the word `heritage' in our proposed amendment, our words are taken directly from the national forest policy statement. Those words, as we have reflected them, read:
conservation of the full range of values that forests can provide for current and future generations, including biological diversity and heritage, indigenous and other cultural values . . .

It needs to be clearly understood by the Democrats and the chamber that the objection is not directly to the phrases or the words that they have put forward; rather, it is based on the principle of ensuring that we accurately reflect what was included within the 11 goals of the national forest policy statement.

I might add that the concepts that the Democrats are referring to in these particular amendments, namely, the use of the words `conservation' and `ecological', are picked up elsewhere in the objects in any event. On that basis, we do not really believe that we should start tampering with the words that were written down in those 11 national goals of the national forest policy statement. If we are going to have an objects clause as we say there should be and if that objects clause is to ensure that this legislation is based on the national forest policy statementâas the government itself saysâthen it is important that we accurately reflect the wording that was in that statement.

talk.start.para: âI would like to respond very briefly to some of Senator Brown's statements. I would also like to ask if these two pieces of paper which have been kindly passed on to me by Senator Calvert could be incorporated in Hansard or tabled. I will just speak briefly to them and then I am happy to do with them whatever the Senate decides.
âCould you pass copies to Senator Forshaw and other senators so that they can have a look at them while you are making your comments?

âYes, certainly. The two charts briefly detail the fact that, unlike the image that Senator Brown has portrayed, there is an enormous part of Tasmania which, incrementally over the last 20 years, has become part of the national parks system and even in this last year or two is already part of the RFA reserve system. Unlike the image that he would give, of most of Tasmania being ablaze, the fact is that Tasmania as a state has an enormous part of its land mass already locked up for those environmental objectives that he wishes to achieve.

speech.para: I cannot let the moment pass without pointing out that in the last 20 years so much investment by any industry has been scared away from Tasmania by the activities of Senator Brown and his cohort. It literally scares off investment from his state. Is it any wonder that investment and jobs are departing his state at a rapid rate, when investment companies and other people who wish to invest money in Tasmania that would provide regional jobs simply do not have the incentive to do so, because of Senator Brown's activities?

talk.start.para: âThe question is: is leave granted for the documents produced by Senator Troeth to be incorporated in Hansard , subject to Hansard being able to reproduce them? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

âI will also seek leave from the chamber to incorporate the picture that I held up a little while ago of the Tarkine wilderness, if Hansard can reproduce it. Senators may remember that I circulated that some months ago. If senators wish, I will circulate copies of that in a little while and then maybe the matter can be determined.
âYou can seek leave at that time, when they have been circulated, Senator Brown.

âThank you. Firstly, I want to have the government answer questions when they are put in committee. There is no point in having a committee process if we have the government unable or unwilling to answer very basic questions on this matter.

speech.para: We come to this heartland matter, which is involved in the question of whether we should support the amendments brought forward by Senator Greig and the minister's own words that the regional forest agreements involved ecologically sustainable logging. I asked the minister quite explicitly if that meant that the ecosystems are sustained, where you have a cut down, firebomb and poison regime as happens with clear-felling in Tasmania's forests. Can the minister assure the chamber that those ecosystems are sustained when that triple process of cut down, firebomb and poison takes place in a wild forest, for example, in the case I showed, the rainforests of the Tarkine wilderness?

talk.start.para: âI simply respond to Senator Brown by saying that this process is a regional process. It is considered as a region, not in specific places such as Senator Brown has shown us in his photograph. On a regional basis, it is an ecologically sustainable process.

âI think Senator Troeth is the determined regionalist here, in that she is avoiding the core question. She, not I, has referred to logging under the RFA system as `ecologically sustainable'. We are not going to get very far here, because the government representative is simply not going to answer this question. If an honest answer were to be given to the question, we would then have the lie given to the abuse of the term `ecologically sustainable' in a process which is utterly ecologically destructive. The parliamentary secretary is, like all of us, part of nature's creativity, and we only have to imagine how we would go if we were in the path of a firebombing process, let alone the logging process before it and the poisoning process afterwards, to recognise that ecosystems are wrecked by this logging.

speech.para: Yet I hear the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Bacon, and the Deputy Premier, Mr Lennon, proceeding with this utter falsehood all the time. The whole concept of ecological sustainability when it comes to the logging of wild forests from Western Australia to Queensland is a lie, but it is presented time and time again, not because it could or should be otherwise handled but because there is determined dishonesty involved in it. I think that the purveyors of this dishonesty should be honest and face up to the reality that they are involved in the destruction of ecosystems, wildlife, nesting sites, river systems, water catchments and understorey, let alone these wondrous ancient forests themselves, and stop trying to kid us that they are doing something that they are not.

The public can see through this. That is why in Western Australia, for example, where recent events have led to heightened public awareness, Minister Wilson Tuckey and other representatives of the woodchip industry have been unable to wind back public concern. The opinion polls have gone in the other direction. It used to be that 70 per cent of people opposed the destruction of what is left of Australia's forest domain, then it was 80 per cent, and a recent opinion poll in Western Australia showed 89 per cent. We have the government saying, `We have had to wind that back a bit.' Richard Court had to respond, because of dissension amongst those people in the government's own ranks who are no longer prepared to live this lie.

talk.start.para: âAsk the timber workers.

âWhat we have to say to the timber workers in Tasmania relates to the promise of this legislationâand I will keep coming back to this. I am very happy to take you on, Senator Troeth, on the jobs issue, not on some speculative basis but on the reality.
âHow many jobs have you created in Tasmania?

âAnd Senator Calvert behind you knows this: the regional forest agreement, which gave the loggers lay down misere in Tasmania, was to secure jobs, but it has led to hundreds of people being put out of work by you, by this government, through this process which simply said to the board rooms in Melbourne and Sydney and Tokyo, `You're in control; they are interested in downsizing, get rid of the workers and you will increase your profit line. We are moving out; we are vacating our responsibilities.' That is what this legislation is about.

speech.para: Let me come back to this: our debate here is based on the fundamental lie that ecological sustainability has been brought to the forest. When you have a political debate based on a lie, nobody is going to rely on the outcome. Nor can those people who have the outcome of this debate and this legislation foisted on them be expected to accept that outcome. What is being purveyed here is totally dishonest.

The minister said that she had been in Tasmania and had gone from Triabunna to Arthur Peninsula during that visit. One has to ask: was that in an empty log truck going from the Triabunna woodchip mill, the first woodchip mill in Tasmania, back into the magnificent spectacle of the Arthur Peninsula, which depends on tourism for its jobs and which is now targeted by this government and this parliamentary secretary and this legislation? Did the minister go to the prominent Mount Koonya, which is the backdrop for all the tourists going to that region and which was protected as a deferred forest but is now the target of the woodchippers under this legislationâagainst the wishes of the locals who know that, besides the scenic amenity and the job prospects that come out of the delight of that area and its natural backdrop, their water catchments are going to be sullied and their environment is going to be invaded by the procession of log trucks, which goes into the hundreds of thousands each year across Tasmania, and the noise and squalor that come with it?

If the parliamentary secretary, Senator Troeth, was in that region, I ask her whether she looked at the other side of the equation. Did she get together with the locals who do not want those forests cut down? Did she go to Mount Koonya? Did she have a look at the impact on water catchments? Did she get an assessment of the destruction of wildlife in that region? Did she speak to tourist operators whose jobs and livelihoods depend on keeping places like Mount Koonya intact? Finally, did she go to see the log truck drivers who used to drive to the Triabunna mill but who were thrown out of their jobs by North Broken Hill, the woodchipper, while the Labor and Liberal parties of the day sat on their hands? I had the drivers come to my office in Tasmania and say, `What do we do here? They assured the jobs, we've got the contracts, now we are going to the wall. We are going to have our houses and other property sold over our heads. We lose everything because the company which said, "We need your services to bring logs to this woodchip mill" has now said that they don't want our services. We have invested $Â¼ million in a log truck and we have those repayments and suddenly we have no business.'

What did they do? I advised them to drive their log trucks in front of Parliament House like the woodchip industry does so readily in abusing, I think, the industry and the feelings of these workers who think that if they go along with the woodchip industry they will have their jobs secured. History now shows that repeatedly that is not the case. The big corporations, who are hand in hand with the parliamentary secretary's party, are interested in getting rid of jobs. That is their profit line. They are not interested in either the forests or the wellbeing of the workers. They might be funding the Forest Protection Society to get out and do their jobs, but I will get to this a little later because we will get more specially into the jobs arena. I am just responding to Senator Troeth's diversion. Forest Protection Society cardholders were sacked in recent weeks, after all the devotion they have given to a system which was supposed to keep their jobs.

I ask the parliamentary secretary again: did you go and see the people in the tourist industry who oppose the regional forest agreements? Did you express concern about their jobs when you were on the Arthur Peninsula? Did you go to Mount Koonya or the townships which depend on tourism there? And did you get a feeling about the other side of the story when you were in Tasmania?

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the amendments moved by Senator Greig be agreed to.
âI wonder if the minister is going to respond to the very important questions I just put to herâor is she unable to?
âThe minister did not respond and therefore I did not call her.

âI thought that may have been because she was diverted or was still thinking. I think the opportunity should be given, because I would like to see her on her feet and answering.
