That is not what a Senate committee system is about. A Senate committee system is to get answers from those people bringing forward legislation which are germane to senators then making up their minds about amendments. We have an amendment from Democrat Senator Greig at the moment which wants to extend the terms of reference of a taxpayer funded councilâwhich is going to be set up at the end of this process if the government has its way but which seems to give representation to the loggers but none to the environmentalists. I think that representation would be fair enough. I think the public would want to see the environmental interest there and would welcome this amendment. Senator Troeth has entered into the debate. I have given her some questions, including very simple ones about her own itinerary in Tasmania. I would expect she would be able to inform the committee and, if she is going to default on that, I think the whole process here is going to be greatly devalued.

âI do respond to questions that I consider important. I consider Senator Brown's questions of me entirely rhetorical. I do not propose to deliver my itinerary of any visit to Tasmania. Suffice it to say that I consult with people regularly throughout regional Australia in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Formerly that portfolio was known as the ministry for primary industry, and industry is what we are on about hereâthe future of the timber industry, the future of the tourism industry and the future of all industries in regional Australia. That is what this legislation is setting out to do: to ensure that all of those voices are heard before, during and after the passage of this legislation to ensure that all of those interests are covered. I consider that my prime responsibility is to listen to those people and to make my contribution to government legislation.

speech.para: Senator Brown, as I indicated before, through the existence of his party, has driven investment and jobs away from his own state. All Tasmanian senators, with the possible exception of him, would sincerely regret that. As an Australian senator I regret that. It is because we do not wish to see his intimidation and his tactics used in other states that we have set out this comprehensive system of dealing with the forests. That is why I totally reject any of Senator Brown's insinuations. I will answer questions that I consider important. I do not consider Senator Brown's questions to be important.

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Troeth for that, because she has at least indicated that she has been in discussions with the tourism industryâand I will come back to that in a moment. Firstly, I will respondâbecause I am happy to respond to her inherent questionsâto the comment about jobs in Tasmania. Let us look at the Franklin River scheme, which she and her government wanted to push in Tasmania. It would have led to a sum total of 32 jobs maximum now, had it gone ahead, but it would have been an enormous financial burden on the state, which in turn leads to job shedding.

speech.para: What Senator Calvert, who is sitting behind Senator Troeth, can tell her is that the one town that is going ahead on the west coast does not depend on logging, does not depend on dam building and certainly does not depend on miningâthat is, Strahan. That is the centre of investment and job creation on the west coast, because the Greens and the community in Tasmania fought against a muddle-headed and wrong process which served the interests of a very small sector of the heavy industry component of Tasmanian manufacturing back in the early 1980sâan industry which has since serially failed.

What we are seeing here is more of that. It is 1982 in 1999, when this legislation is meant to lock in the interests of woodchip industriesâwhich are based outside Tasmania, which have more than 90 per cent of their shareholders outside the state and which export the jobs to the mainland and to Japan. I will defend the Greens as having the only philosophy of a clean green producing state based on service industries, on tourism and on clean green agriculture from winegrowing, cheese production and so on in Tasmania.

What we have now is a very competitive situation as far as forests are concerned. There are some 18,000 jobs based in the service industries and tourism in Tasmania which the Greens support, which the Greens have helped build up and which are increasing in numbers. Over 3,000 of those jobs are dependent on the beauty of the forestsâwhich Senator Troeth has acknowledgedâand those jobs are growing in number.

The competitive woodchip industry wants to knock those forests downâI referred to Mount Koonya earlier as a sterling example, which Senator Troeth would have seen, even if she did not recognise it in her travelling to Tasmaniaâand the destruction of that amenity would be a direct inhibition to job growth and investment in tourism and service industries in Tasmania. The industry will tell you that. If Senator Troeth has truly spoken to them, she will know that, even though she might not want to tell this committee.

This legislation, which was to promise jobs in the forest industry, has failed. Hundreds of jobs have been shed since it was signed. So we have got an industry which is cutting more forest but because it is automating is shedding jobs, ranged up against an industry which is putting on jobs, and good quality jobs, and is involved in long-term local investment, and which will have its opportunity lost if the woodchippers have their way. You cannot have this both ways. There is a failure of understanding of this dynamic which infects the big parties. I think Labor at the federal level is a mile ahead of the government in this respect. Unfortunately, the Bacon Labor government in Tasmania is miles behind. It is even worse at state level than the Liberals here when it comes to recognising this, because it wanted last year to knock down even more forest than the Liberals.

The fundamental question that comes out of all of this is to ask Senator Troeth, who says she is concerned about regional jobs, including tourism, which tourist entities she spoke to on that visit to south-east Tasmania. Would Senator Troeth be good enough to give the committee any detail about any person she met in the tourist industry, or any representative of the tourist industry that she met, in that visit to a very job creating industry in an important part of the spectrum in Tasmania, which is the Triabunna and Port Arthur area?

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the amendments moved by Senator Greig be agreed to.

âI think this is going to become part of a pretty sad litany of defaults by Senator Troeth. I have to say that if a representative ministerâthis is in fact the role she is taking on this very important legislationâcannot even answer a question about whom she spoke to in the tourism industry, one is left to assume she spoke to no-one. That is the fact of the matter. She did not contact the tourism industry. She did not contact those people whose jobs are likely to be lost because of her actions through this legislation. You see, when you do not do that, you do not have the balance that Senator Troeth talks about. You are not informed. You are not competent to be working in the best interests of the wider community, including in particular those people who want jobs, let alone those people who want the environment protected. It is a pretty sad situation we have here as far as Senator Troeth and this government are concerned. She has Senator Calvert sitting behind her, and he has got no answer to this either.

speech.para: The reality is that this is the wrong way for Tasmania to be treated and similarly the wrong way for the other states, from Western Australia through to south-east Queensland, to be treated. It is also the wrong way for a committee in the Senate dealing with an important matter like this to be treated by the government representative.
Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that opposition amendments R1 and 2 on sheet 1290 revised 2 be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move Australian Greens amendment No. 1 on sheet 1265:

speech.para: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (lines 7 and 8), omit the definition of comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system , substitute:
comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system , in relation to an RFA, means a dedicated reserve system that meets:
(a) the biodiversity criteria; and
(b) the old-growth forest criteria; and
(c) the wilderness criteria;

of the nationally agreed criteria for the establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative Reserve System for forests in Australia (the JANIS criteria), published in January 1997 by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council/Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture National Forest Policy Statement Implementation Sub-committee.

This is to deal with the definition of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system, `comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve' being the words which lead to it being called the CARR system. The definition that we have in this very thin documentâthe Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 âsays:
comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system , in relation to an RFAâ
a regional forest agreementâ
has the same meaning as in the RFA.

In other words, we as a parliament are to go and look at a document signed outside the parliamentâunless amendments coming further down the line get through in this placeâto find out what the definition of `comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system' is. It is left to a Premierâit could be Mr Kennett in Victoria, Mr Court in Western Australia or Mr Bacon in Tasmania; they are all of similar mind when it comes to the destruction of forestsâto work out with the Prime Minister what the definition will be.

Presumablyâand I think in realityâthere will be different definitions in different regional forest agreements. That is a very unsatisfactory situation for us to have. There should be the same definition across the country. Moreover, it should not be left to the parliament to put into legislation a definition which is not a production of this parliament or this committee but has been left to politicians signing documents somewhere else outside our jurisdiction. We have a responsibility to say exactly what is meant by `a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system' and I have moved to do that. In this amendment I propose that we omit the failed definition that the government has put and have these words instead:
comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system , in relation to an RFA,
means a dedicated reserve system that meets:
(a) the biodiversity criteria; and
(b) the old-growth forest criteria; and
(c) the wilderness criteria;
of the nationally agreed criteria for the establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative Reserve System for forests in Australia (the JANIS criteria),â
there are other technical words which we can put in there for completenessâ

published in January 1997 by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council/Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture National Forest Policy Statement Implementation Sub-committee.
That at least gives us a clear anchor on what is meant by `comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system', which is fundamental to this legislation.

Senator Troeth has said that she is representing the very ministry that was on that council that devised this definition, so I think she should have very little difficulty in supporting this amendment. In other words, it is her ministerially agreed amendment that we are using. It is not a Green derivation. It is a government one and, for that matter, a definition agreed by all state governments and the New Zealand government. Let us not leave it to changes or variations to that definition which might be in regional forest agreements. Let us bring it up into this legislation where all citizens and all people who are involved in the outcome of this legislation will know what it means.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 12.45 p.m., I now call upon matters of public interest.

âWhen Judie Stephens's grandson Jackson was three months old, he sustained a very serious head injury in a motor vehicle accident that killed both of his parents. The current expenditure for Jackson's 24-hour care, rehabilitation, active observation and equipment is between $3,000 and $4,500 per week. That is why I want to draw to the attention of this chamber today the practical benefits of structured settlements. Generally speaking, common law practice provides that compensation in cases of serious injury can be awarded either as a tax-free lump sum or as periodic payments subject to income tax. The tax-free nature of the lump sum payment makes it the preferred option for many claimants, but it requires responsible and complex management if it is to provide for the long-term care of the disabled party. Structured settlements, on the other hand, provide a secure income for the beneficiary for lifeâan income that can pay for ongoing medical care while promoting the independence of the claimant.

speech.para: It is my firm conviction that legislation that enables seriously disabled accident victims to access tax-free structured settlements would be a responsible step forward for the management of disability care. The structured settlement proposal is designed to benefit both accident victims and all taxpaying Australians. Structured settlements would be available to any seriously injured individual who is entitled to common law compensation payouts. Such settlements are the way of paying common law compensation periodically. So, instead of a single lump sum, claimants can receive a smaller up-front lump sum payment combined with ongoing tax-free periodic payments for the rest of their life. This arrangement would offer seriously injured people greater long-term financial security and would reduce the risk of seriously injured accident victims becoming reliant on government welfare.

Structured settlements are supported by international precedent, with the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Canada undertaking the necessary taxation reform to introduce tax-free structured components of compensation awards. Wherever common law damages for personal injury are paid, a structured settlement can be used. It includes motor vehicle accidents, work injuries, medical malpractice and public liability but excludes statutory periodic payments. During the settlement negotiation process, either party can suggest a structured settlement and, if both parties agree, the case can be settled on this basis.

The design of each structure will depend on the individual needs of the injured party. However, overseas experience indicates that usually about one-third of the compensation is paid to the claimant as an up-front lump sum and the rest is then used by the defendant insurer to purchase an annuity for the injured person. The annuity funds the periodic payments, which are normally payable for the life of the injured person, and they are indexed to inflation. There is usually a minimum guarantee period, and if a claimant dies before the expiration of that period the payments will continue to be made to the claimant's estate or to the nominated beneficiary. After the defendant insurer purchases the annuity, it obtains a full release from liability and can close its file. The annuity is owned by the insured person, who has an ongoing relationship with the provider. As previously stated, tax-free structured settlements have been adopted in the USA, the United Kingdom and Canada. The relevant compensation and taxation laws in Australia are nearly identical to those in the United Kingdom, making the English model the most appropriate for Australia to adopt.

The sad reality is that lump sum payments are too frequently an inadequate form of compensation. Those in receipt of lump sum payments are often at the mercy of ill-informed or unscrupulous carers, and poor investment choices often result. Large sums of money are difficult to handle and a false sense of wealth and security can lead to a rapidly diminishing resource. Lump sum payments must be particularly well managed if they are to provide for the long-term interests of the claimantâa significant responsibility to be borne by the beneficiary or their carer. The difficulties involved in managing large sums should not be underestimated. It would be difficult for any one of us, if paid our lifetime's income in one lump sum today, to manage that money so that it lasts as long as we live. The problems can only be magnified when the money is paid to accident victims who are already having to deal with the enormous physical and emotional stress caused by their ongoing disabilities.

Even if a lump sum were to be invested and spent by a claimant carefully, it may not last. This is because the assumptions on which the sum was calculated may not prove to be accurate. Lump sum settlements are calculated based on assumptions about future interest rates, inflation and, sometimes, the claimant's mortality. The solution is not simply to shift the risk of inaccurate assumptions from claimants to defendants but to shift the risk to the life insurer from whom the structured settlement is purchased. Life insurers are able to make realistic, market based predictions and are better placed to handle the associated risks. When lump sums are exhausted, the severely disabled beneficiary often becomes reliant on social security and Medicare to meet the costs of their care, rehabilitation and living expenses. Thus the problem of the lump sum payments paid in inappropriate circumstances affects every one of us. Once the money is gone, it is only a matter of time before beneficiaries turn to the government for support.

A 1997 report by Coopers and Lybrand conservatively estimated that in any one year recipients of lump sum payments cost the Australian government $225 million. This figure was achieved by calculating the current cost of social security and Medicare for lump sum beneficiaries and deducting it from the total taxation revenue collected from periodic payment recipients. Thus, despite a loss of taxation revenue, the government would actually save money by implementing a structured settlement scheme.

While accident victims could now request payment of their common law compensation in the form of periodic payments, this does not happen. Injured people tend to prefer lump sums because of their tax-free status and defendants tend to prefer lump sums because they avoid any ongoing administrative costs. Under a structured settlement scheme, ongoing administrative costs are undertaken by the provider and the compensation is finalised at the time of settlement, and the disincentive of ongoing administrative costs for the defendant is thus avoided. Unless the law is changed to encourage structured settlements, the status quo will remain unchanged. That would be to the detriment of many claimants, many defendant insurers and certainly all taxpayers.

Many interest groups regularly approach the government and request tax breaks. We know a certain degree of caution needs to be adopted when we deal with such requests. Structured settlements are, however, a special case on the basis of strong policy and economic grounds. The special tax treatment would only be available to those who have suffered personal injuries and who have elected to receive their compensation periodically. This group of people would be relatively small and comprised of seriously injured people. Few other interest groups seeking tax concessions will be able to justify their call for tax breaks on such a significant social justice basis, nor is their proposed change likely to be revenue positive for the government.

I believe that, through the introduction of structured settlements in Australia, the government has the opportunity to benefit both individuals suffering severe injury and all Australian taxpayers. All compensation stakeholdersâinjured people, insurers and lawyersâsupport this reform which will greatly improve the compensation system in Australia. There are a number of people who have been quoted as giving unanimous support for structured settlements: the New South Wales Law and Justice Committee in 1996, the Victorian Law Reform Committee in 1997, and an NRMA submission to the Law and Justice Committee in 1998. With those few words, I encourage everyone in this chamber to show support for what would be a vitally important initiative.

talk.start.para: âI wish to speak on a matter of public interest which has importance for the individuals affected and as an example of the policy failure of the Howard government's so-called aged care reforms. I speak today about the experience of a group of health workers in Victoriaânurses, domestics and orderly staffâwho are owed up to $50,000 in wages and termination entitlements following the closure of the Alimar Nursing Home in Essendon. Those staff lost their jobs when the home closed in January this year. Some of the workers are now pursuing their entitlements via their union and through action in the courts. Unfortunately, the othersâmany of them migrants with limited English language skillsâhave been forced to accept their loss and their powerlessness. Because of their small numbers and the lack of access to publicity, these workers, many of whom were very low paid, stand to lose thousands of dollars of accrued entitlements. They will not be granted the consideration the Oakdale miners eventually gained from this government.

speech.para: This is one of many examples of workers losing their entitlements when a business closes down and the employer fails, or is unable, to meet their obligations. In this case, and in the case of nursing homes generally, there are important issues of government accountability and public policy at stake. The Commonwealth pays to the owner of the nursing home a range of subsidies that effectively pay for the care needs of these older Australians. They are, in large part, Commonwealth subsidised providers. The Commonwealth pays a daily care subsidy for each resident that varies from $60.46 per day to $109.72 per day. In the case of the Alimar Nursing Home, these subsidies would have totalled $1.2 million a year. This is $1.2 million a year of taxpayers' money to pay for the proper care of these older Australians in that nursing home. The subsidy is intended to cover the cost of providing care for residents and, most significantly, to cover the labour related costs, which include the costs of wages, long service leave, superannuation and workers' compensation. In other words, the Commonwealth is effectively paying for the wages of the care workers employed in the industry.

In addition, the Commonwealth pays a concessional resident supplement of up to $12.34 a day where a person is unable to afford the government's accommodation chargeâthat is, charges are levied on residents and/or the Commonwealth to finance the capital upgrading of the employers' premises to ensure that the premises are of high quality and suitable for the care of the aged. In addition to what a provider is paid for the care of the elderly, they also get from either the resident or the Commonwealth up to $12 a day; moneys which are designed to provide for the capital upgrading and to meet the costs of providing a good quality nursing home. So we are providing moneys for not only the care of the elderly but also the capital infrastructure to provide that care. The Commonwealth and the Minister for Aged Care are responsible and accountable for those funds.

In the case of the Alimar Nursing Home and others like it, there are serious allegations that the department and the minister have failed to properly protect the public interest in terms of the care of the residents and the use of Commonwealth funds. The residents are entitled to protection not only because they pay 85 per cent of their pension, or $307 a fortnight, to cover the costs of expenses like meals and laundry while they are living there but also because they are entitled toâand we demandâa decent standard of care. Those residents who can afford it are also required to pay up to $4,380 a year through the government's accommodation charge, depending on their assets. Again, this is their contribution to the provider so they can afford to provide proper capital infrastructure for the nursing homeâthe buildings and the equipmentâso that the home is of a sufficient standard to ensure good quality care. The residents, along with the Commonwealth, are contributing to the payment for the cost of the care and the buildings in which that care is provided. Of course, the residents might also be liable for the income tested fee that has been in the news more recently. So the funding of nursing homes is largely from the Commonwealth but there is also a contribution from the residents.

The Alimar Nursing Home is one that had failed to meet the bare minimum standards of care required. In an inspection of the home in October 1998, the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency found that there were serious risks to the health and wellbeing of residents. The report identified serious risks in the areas of health and personal care and the physical environment of the nursing home. The inspectors found pans and urine bottles soaking in a sanitising solution. These were not fully immersed, so that increases the risk of serious infection. The inspection team found a number of failings in the standard of cleanliness of the facility and found that the residents did not always receive appropriate clinical care in the nursing home. The inspection found, in total, eight separate instances of serious risk to the health and wellbeing of residents at the home in October last year. `Serious risk' is the highest category of concern that they can express.

We have a nursing home that is clearly not up to standard, where the health of the residents is at risk because the standards are not up to scratch. This is a nursing home that is largely financed by the Commonwealth and partly by a contribution from the residents. What happened as a result? It seems that, despite the contributions made by the Commonwealth and its responsibilities in this matter, the owner of the nursing home was allowed to close it in January this year and move to sell the bed licences, which we understand will net him in the order of $1 million. What action was taken to ensure that the money that the Commonwealth and the residents paid in was used for the purpose for which it was designed? None, as far as I can tell. The owner was allowed to run down the facility, rip off the residents, pocket the money, fail to pay the wages of the nurses and other staff at the home, then obtain the department's approval to sell the bed licences and pocket a further $1 million from the sale.

This is a disgrace. This is Commonwealth taxpayers' and older Australians' money that has been ripped off. They have not been provided with a decent service, the workers have not been paid their entitlements, no capital improvements funded by the Commonwealth and the residents have taken place, and this character has been allowed to leave the industry, pocketing the money from both the residents and the Commonwealth and the money from the sale of the licences. I want to know why that was allowed to happen, the former employees want to know why it was allowed to happen, and the relatives of the residents want to know how it was allowed to happen.

These concernsâparticularly about the employees' entitlementsâwere raised with the department as soon as they were alerted to the closure. The unions and employees were contacting the department saying, `We are concerned about our entitlements. The owner of the Alimar Nursing Home has been underpaying wages. We are concerned that the entitlements of the employees need to be protected. We want your assistance in protecting those.' I know now that those employees are having to seek restitution through the courts. They are having difficulty tracing the owner, and we understand that he has been allowed by the department to sell his licence and leave the industry.

This is a character that the department said was running a nursing home that posed a serious risk to the residents. The department had assessed him as being unsuitable in his care of the residents, but we continued to pump Commonwealth funds into his operation and we continued to pay him $12 a day per concessional resident for a capital upgrade of his facility that we knew he had no intention of making. He is one of a small number of providers who will not meet the certification and accreditation standards that are coming into place. His vested interest is in running the facility down, providing poor quality care, making as big a quid as he can out of older Australians in the meantime and fleeing the industry by selling his bed licences at a very healthy rate and pocketing the profit from those. All the time, a provider like this is running a substandard facility. He is pocketing the residents' pension incomes, the Commonwealth care funds, the concessional supplement and the residents' contributions towards capital improvement.

What did the Alimar Nursing Home owner have to do in return? Absolutely nothing. The one test that the government applies to him is to send around the accreditation agency to assess whether or not he is providing proper care to the residents. They did that in October and they found out that he was not providing proper care and that the sort of care provided posed a serious risk to the health of the residents.

What happens? In January of the following year, he is allowed to quietly close the nursing home, leave his employees without their proper wage and termination entitlements and sell his bed licences with ministerial or departmental approval. So we and the older Australians living in this nursing home have funded the owner to provide substandard care, to pocket the money that should have been spent on their care, to pocket the money that should have been spent on the capital upgrade of the facility, to pocket the money from the sale of the government's licence for nursing home beds and then to leave the industry. That is an absolute disgrace.

I want to know what the department has done to protect the interests of residents; I want to know what the department has done to protect the interests of the Commonwealth; and I want to know what the minister has done to protect the financial interests of the Commonwealth. It seems to me that there is a small but not insignificant number of nursing home providers, particularly in Victoria, who have embarked on the same course of actionâthat is, to run inferior nursing home facilities until such time as the certification and accreditation standards catch up with them, at which time they know that, without any penalty, they will be allowed to sell the beds for a profit and leave the industry.

I want to know what protection there is for employees and their entitlements when that occurs. I want to know what action the minister is taking to protect the hundreds of thousands of Commonwealth dollars that are going to those providers for capital improvements but are not used for those improvements. Why do we pay a provider who is going to leave the industry $12 a day per resident so that they can pocket the money and not spend it on capital upgrades? It is a disgrace.

Why do we require that elderly Australians, many in their 80s and 90s, have to findâin addition to their pensionâ$12 a day so that they can contribute towards the upgrade of a facility when the provider has no intention of upgrading the facility which, on the department's own assessment, forces them to live in conditions that pose a serious health risk? In addition to losing all their pension towards meeting the cost of the nursing home, they now have to pay an extra $12 a day so that the character who owns the nursing home can pocket that money and put it towards his own retirement income. It is an absolute disgrace.

Pensioners are being forced to find money that many of them do not have and many of them cannot afford with no guarantee that any of that money is used for the improvement of their facility. The government makes no requirement that that money be used for capital upgrades. It seems that it makes no requirement that the nursing care of the elderly that it pays for is actually delivered, no requirement that the funds it pays to the provider are used for that purpose. In fact, when the facility was inspected, it was found that it was not meeting basic standards and that proper care is not being provided. What does the Commonwealth do? It writes another cheque. It keeps on providing money and it keeps on requiring the residents to provide money while the provider is running down the facility and running down the service, knowing that there is no sanction against them, there is no comeback, there is no accountability for the Commonwealth's or the residents' funds, and at the end of the day they will get a nice little profit from the bed licence, because they are allowed to sell it without any questions being asked.

I want to ask these questions. Why aren't they required to ensure that the money they collect for capital is used for capital purposes? Why aren't they required to ensure that the money we pay them for care is used for care and that the care is provided? Why aren't they required to ensure that before they leave the industry the entitlements of the employees who have worked for them are met? Those are questions that the department and the minister need to answer before we get even more examples of the sort of disgrace that Alimar Nursing Home represents.

talk.start.para: âThe matter that I wish to raise in today's debate is the proposed legislation put before the Tasmanian parliament by the state Labor government in relation to industrial changes in my home state of Tasmania. It should be noted that the changes are being proposed by the Labor Premier, Jim Bacon, whose great claim to fame was that he was the former Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation in Tasmania.

speech.para: Indeed, Tasmanians still recall that, when Tasmania was without its crossing of the Derwent River as a result of that unfortunate accident in 1975, Mr Bacon in his then capacity as the Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation stopped the concrete pour on the second bridge that was being built, the Bowen Bridge, on the basis that he asserted that it had commenced raining. The fact is that the Bureau of Meteorology recorded that not a single drop of rain fell in Hobart or in its vicinity on that particular day.

So that is the sort of fellow we are dealing with. Sure, when he decided he would seek Labor Party preselection and get into parliament, he donned the suits and the silk ties, trimmed his moustache and tried to look smooth and good. To a certain extent the new image worked and, yes, he did win the last election. But the old Secretary of the BLF has come out well and truly with these proposals.

The reason I am bringing these proposals before the Senate is twofold. One is to inform the people of Tasmania that they do have an opportunity to reject this legislation, at least in part, in the Legislative Council elections this coming Saturday in the seats of Murchison, Pembroke and Rumney, where the Labor Party are desperately running candidatesâmight I add, each and every one of them is a failed House of Assembly candidate. The Labor Party are trying to stack them into the upper house with a view to, and hope of, getting this legislation passed through the upper house. So the people of Tasmania do have an opportunity this coming Saturday to cast a protest vote, and I would encourage them to do so.

The other point of this debate is to encourage businesses in the event that this legislation does get through the Tasmanian parliament to consider the very real benefits of the Australian workplace agreements that are now available to them; in other words, they ought to opt out of the state system into the federal system and get basically the same benefits of the enterprise agreements. It is very interesting to note that in Tasmania there are currently 482 enterprise agreements registered under legislation which the Groom Liberal government introduced not that many years ago. There are already 482 signed-up agreements in operation, covering 5,996 workers, as at 30 July this year. If you divide that, it means about 12 workers per enterprise agreement. What does that tell you? These enterprise agreements are for the benefit of workers and small businesses because they allow flexibility and they allow arrangements to be made for the benefit of workers and small enterprise.

What do we know about small businesses? They are the engine room of the economyâthat is the mantra of both sides of politics. The Labor Party and we on this side, as the government, admit that the engine room of the economy and future jobs growth is small businesses. Small businesses have taken to these enterprise agreements and workplace agreements because they suit them, they work well for them and they work well for their employees. They work for workers because in Tasmania, for an enterprise agreement to get through, you need 60 per cent of the work force to agree to that arrangement. So it is not simply a 50 per cent plus one vote but a 60 per cent margin, which really does protect the interests of the workers.

A study was done in recent times into the state enterprise agreement system in Tasmania, and what did it show? It showed jobs growth in those businesses that had enterprise agreements. In the state of Tasmaniaâwhich suffers the greatest unemployment of any state and where, at best, the economy is sluggishâbusinesses that are showing jobs growth are those that have embraced enterprise agreements and workplace agreements. They are able to be flexible for the benefit of their work force and for the benefit of their business; therefore, it is a true win-win situation.

To try to distract attention from this draconian state legislation, the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council have orchestrated a series of rallies around my home state of Tasmania, allegedly on the basis of campaigning against Mr Reith's federal legislation.

talk.start.para: âThey are about the second wave.

âSenator Mackay is interjecting. I suggest you ring up the Tasmanian Treasurer, David Crean, and ask him to look out his window and see how many people are actually at the rally at Parliament House in Tasmania. I am advised that, as at 12.30 this afternoon, there were only 70 or 75 people at that rally. There would be more trade union officials and paid Labor Party officials than those 70 or 75 that turned out for that rally in Hobart. The question has to be asked: why is it that even trade union officials are staying away from these orches trated rallies? Because they are feeling ashamed of the behaviour of the trade union movement in Tasmania, and they are severely embarrassed by their former BLF Secretary, now Premier, trying to foist this sort of legislation on the people of Tasmania.

speech.para: The Labor Party get all excited because they do not want the people of Tasmania to know what is in this proposed legislation. I want to point out to the Senate todayâand to my fellow Tasmaniansâthat this legislation will basically legalise union thuggery. What it will allow for isâ

talk.start.para: âYou are so boring, Eric.

âSenator Mackay interjects and says it is boring. Take the tip, Senator Mackay, if you are a small business person or, indeed, if you were a worker in a small business, the one thing you would not want is a trade union official to come into your premises uninvited. Everybody on the premises, including the workers, can object to that trade union official entering through that door but, under this legislation, none of them would have a right to object because it would legalise this group of trade unionists, acting as vigilantes, entering business premises willy-nilly and uninvited. If there is a suspected breach of industrial laws, then it is not for a vigilante group of trade union thugs to enter the workplace. It is for industrial relations officials to enter those premises, search the records and determine if there is any complaint to be made.

speech.para: To simply allow trade union officials to walk in uninvited is completely unacceptable in this day and age. Indeed, as I understand it, the amendments we made to the federal legislation were, in fact, supported and negotiated by a now frontbencher on the ALP side, Cheryl Kernot. The Australian Labor Party want to keep interjectingâwasn't it amazing when I mentioned Cheryl Kernot's name that, just for a moment, they went silent, and I can understand why. There are many people on the Labor side of politics who object to this sort of legalised union thuggery. They do not want trade union officials to be able to walk in uninvited to their business premises and to their workplaces.

Another change that is being proposed is in relation to the enterprise agreement system. As I advised the Senate just before, you need 60 per cent of the workers to vote in favour of it. The Enterprise Commissioner goes through the regularity of that process very carefully and makes a determination as to whether or not the agreement is fair, reasonable and appropriate in all the circumstances. Indeed, what has happened on many occasions is that the workers and employers have got together, made an arrangement which suited them and then gone to the Enterprise Commissioner who ratified it.

But that is not good enough for the trade union movement. Even if they do not have a single member in the workplace and even if each and every single worker objects to union involvement, the union will be entitled to intervene in the proceedings before the Enterprise Commissioner. That is offensive to anybody who has a broad view of Australian society. People ought to be free to enter into arrangements with an independent arbiter; namely, the Enterprise Commissioner.

The enterprise agreement system has worked well in Tasmania. In fact, it has slowed down the huge rate of unemployment in my home state of Tasmania. Yet Labor wants to get rid of the position of Enterprise Commissioner. The Labor Party does not want to see the success of this system. Why? Because it obviates the need for unions. It is based on good employer-employee relations. As a result, the trade unions are dealt out of the scheme, they have fewer members, less income andâguess what?âless money to forward to the Labor Party at election time. That is the real root cause behind Labor's manic determination to push this legislation through in my home state.

The people on the other side of the chamber tell us that they are absolutely committed to the principles of privacy and the rights of individuals. Then why is it that they would want those private arrangements, which are sanctioned by the Enterprise Commissioner, to be put on the public record? If you have a small enterpriseâ

talk.start.para: âBut it is no good if they are secret.
âThey are secret.
âLet's see them if they are so good.

âSenator Sherry and Senator Mackay say, `If they are so good, then why don't you show them.' There are competitive advantages. In a small business you might have only three employees. It would be pretty obvious under the job descriptions in those agreements who fits into which category. It would be publicly on the record exactly all the benefits that they get, which might include employee bonuses. That might mean, if you are a retailer, that the employee can purchase a whole lot of benefits at a discounted price. That might mean flexible working arrangements for individual workers if they have negotiated that. For businesses to retain a competitive advantage, they should not have to disclose that to their competitors. All they need do under the current system is to disclose it to the Enterprise Commissioner, an independent arbiter, who can determine whether the agreement is appropriate in all the circumstances.

speech.para: In the few moments remaining to me, I would like to stress the importance and benefit of these enterprise agreements and workplace agreements to women workers. The mantra of the Australian Labor Party is such that they continually say, `This is bad for women workers.' But the reality is that it is very good, because if there is one sector of the work force that has craved flexibility because of competing family needs, then it is women. Women want flexible working hours. Indeed, honourable senators and the general public may well rememberâSenators Tierney and Coonan will rememberâthe case in New South Wales concerning a factory full of women employees. The women employees approached management and asked for flexible work hours so that they could drop their kids off at school and pick them up again after school. Who blocked it? The trade union movement blocked it, against the wishes of each and every one of the women in that factory. So the opposition should not come to us on this side, saying that it somehow supports women workers. The people of Tasmania on Saturday have an opportunity to reject this legislation, by voting against Labor candidates in Murchison, Pembroke and Rumney.

talk.start.para: âI would like to raise today a matter of great public concern: the issue of people smuggling. In recent times there has been considerable publicity about the numbers of people paying $20,000 and more, according to press reports, to board a rusty old boat, hoping to land somewhere on the Australian coast. Considerable evidence is now emerging to suggest that there may be many more thousands of people entering Australia through the inappropriate granting of student visa applications.

speech.para: Last Thursday the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, in his usual slippery manner, released late in the day a press release which was headed: `Greater Protection for Overseas Students'. This, of course, would be a matter of great amusement if the issues raised were not so serious. The minister announced a review of the Education Services for Overseas Students Act, known as the ESOS Act. He told us that this was `in line with the commitment to constantly monitor the effectiveness of legislation and policy'. You might ask what was wrong with that. Nothingâif that was in fact true.

What we have seen in recent times is that this minister has effectively ignored the advice that is being tendered to him from a number of sources. We could begin with the advice tendered to him over 12 months agoâan entire year agoâin a report by the Senate education committee last August, which unanimously recommended that the issues raised in that report be considered by government `as a matter of priority'. I want to repeat that: these were recommendations which were endorsed by all senators from all parties `as a matter of priority'. This was a committee report following an inquiry initiated by the Labor opposition. Just five minutes spent listening to or reading some of the evidence given to the committee inquiry would have been enough for even the most obtuse minister to recognise that the education export industry is a ticking time bomb of potential migration rorts and student exploitation.

I would like to emphasise that, while most education providers of overseas students are completely legitimate, it would appear that a lack of coordination between the various government authorities is enabling some organisations to recruit for the purposes of securing a visa rather than an educational course. I am concerned about reports emerging that some unscrupulous, unethical enterprises are now engaging in the use of student visas for a range of activities which are completely at odds with our intentions, as a country, to establish a high-quality education industry. In fact, some of these intentions go to the issue of prostitution.

What we have seen is that the scale of administrative and regulatory problems has escalated. This minister has been content to simply put his head in the sand and pretend that all is well. He has, of course, overseen this situation; he has overseen the administration of an education industry which has seen quality, in my judgment, plummet. We are seeing students being ripped off, and the reputation of the education industry as a quality provider has been left to wither.

Australia's education export industry is worth about $3Â½ billion a year: it is our fourth largest export industry. Competition, we all know, is fierce. We cannot afford to get it wrong. We cannot afford to allow our international reputation as a quality education provider to be damaged. Yet Dr Kemp has done nothing about the issues that were raised over a year ago. The sunset clause of the ESOS Act was extended and will continue through to the beginning of 2002. This situation will continue until Dr Kemp has been pressured by the Labor opposition and until he has been faced with a series of collapses of private education colleges, and front-page scandals.

The minister, of course, has left this announcement far too late. He has also allowed the release, once again, of a misleading press release, in which he says, `I am keen to build on the effectiveness of the regulatory framework.' This implies that the current regulatory framework actually works. I put it to the minister that it does not, and it has not for some years. I ask: has the minister been living on the moon for him not to know this?

For instance, we have seen the use of the trust accounts. Under the ESOS Act, the Commonwealth maintains a register of institutions and courses for overseas students, and requires private education and training providers to maintain trust accounts as an insurance for students should the businesses fail. Since last year's ESOS inquiry, volumes of evidence have emerged showing the absurdity of the minister's and the department's claim that it is adequately auditing these trust accounts. We all know that it is currently done on the basis of a once-per-year operation. We all know that the day after the trust accounts are audited, the money can be withdrawn. We all know that the day before the trust account is audited, money can be added to top up.

We have seen that a kindergarten child could get around this type of regulation. Unscrupulous providers have made a habit of withdrawing funds the day after the audit. In recent times various organisations involved in the industry have pointed to the loopholes that currently exist within these so-called TAS requirements.

We have seen allegations being made of immigration agents now demanding of colleges up to 50 per cent of student feesâwhich in many colleges is some $12,000 a yearâas kickbacks for the provision of students. We have seen allegations now being made about non-attendance records not being kept. We have seen other allegations being raised that some colleges now provide non-attending students with attendance records on the basis of a fee. That is then used for the basis of further extensions of visa applications.

In the state of Victoria we saw the Business Institute of Victoria go into receivership in May this year. The information I had was that that college had no money in its trust accounts at the time of its collapse. The BIV operated English language courses in Melbourne and Vanuatu. Some 20 students from the Melbourne campus were placed at Chalmer's Business College, RMIT and the Central Queensland University's Melbourne campus, but it is not apparent what happened to the rest of the students.

There is clear evidence that a number of students involved in that college were not bona fide students, and never intended to be bona fide students. For instance, a college such as the Business Institute of Victoria, which was registered as a registered training organisation to provide courses in security and cleaning, allowed students to enter the country on visa applications, as the current law allows, and then transferred those same students to MBA courses for which the college at no time was registered.

It was quite illegal for it to do that, yet have we heard of any prosecutions being launched by this department or this minister? Have we heard of any effective regulation being taken in regard to those colleges?

We have further evidence that the same college and the same principals involved with the Business Institute of Victoria engaged in a phoenix operationâthat is, after the college goes bankrupt, within a very short time the son of the principal of the bankrupt company reopens the college accounts and accepts moneys on behalf of students engaged in that college. Yet, again, we see no action being taken by this government or this department.

One could understand this, as there was a 50 per cent reduction in the number of staff available through DETYA to monitor the operations of the overseas college. It is very difficult for hardworking officersâand they are clearly regarded as men and women of great integrityâto actually carry out their job effectively. One could expect that, with a 50 per cent reduction in resources, it is not possible for the government, even if it were prepared to pursue these issues, to do so adequately.

The Business Institute of Victoria, however, was a college that also received support and encouragement from other agencies within government. For instance, it received an export market development grant of $43,000 from Austrade just a few months before it collapsed. Dr Kemp talks of his whole-of-government approach, but when we see the way this overseas students program is operated it is quite apparent that there is not a whole-of-government approach operating within this government.

It is quite apparent that the government in Canberra knows very little about what is occurring within the states. It is quite apparent that within a very short period of time, people who want to join the so-called Commonwealth register of overseas colleges can apply and receive permission to be added to that list. Within 24 hours a name, an address, a fax number and telephone number are provided by the state authority of the department of education in Canberra. Within 24 hours of that, that information is applied to all our posts overseas. So within a very short time, a matter of days after an application for entry to the CRICOS list, you can find that students are able to apply for and be given permission to enter Australia.

We have evidence presented to the Senate committee by the department of immigration on this matter, which I have been pursuing, which clearly demonstrates that they are not effectively in charge of the operation of this scheme either. Each department passes the buck. Immigration does not seem to understand what the department of education is doing and does not seem to care. For that matter, the department of education in Canberra does not seem to care what the states are doing. What we have, for instance, are the questions I asked: is there effective monitoring of the ESOS Act and is an attempt being made by the Commonwealth government to check the bona fides of the fit and proper persons test, for instance, that applies in other aspects of Commonwealth legislation? It does not apply in this area.

In response to a question on notice, we are told that the immigration officials required to decide student visa applications are not able to look behind either the ESOS Act or CRICOS, the Commonwealth registry. So it would appear that the whole-of-government approach this minister is pursuing is totally fallacious. We have the case, for instance, I raised in the Senate just a fortnight ago at question time. I have yet to receive an answer concerning that operation of the National College of Australia, where, I remind the Senate, some 300 students appear to have gone missing.

Three months after the college collapsed this government is not able to advise the Senate where these students are and what they are doing. I think you are entitled to seek advice as to why the department was not able to have records that were consistent with the advice given to the company investigators that were handling the liquidation. Some 600 overseas students were on the company records, yet the department seems to have known about only 232.

We are entitled to know why it wasâaccording to DETYA recordsâthat only 15 students were placed in other institutions and only 53 students applied for refunds of their fees. What happened to the rest of the students? We are entitled to know why the department did not have addresses for those students and was not able to contact them immediately the college collapsed. We are entitled to know why the insurance company, the Australian Underwriting Agencies, was refusing to pay students who were seeking payments for the loss of fees. It was becauseâas I understandâthe insurance company had clear evidence that fraud was involved in the collapse.

Ralph Bidwell, the principal of the college, did commit suicide and made it difficult to inquire as to the exact arrangements as to why the records of the college were destroyed. It was difficult to inquire why it was that so many students were enrolled in the college but were not registered with the Commonwealth.

We have a major problem here and I would ask the minister, in terms of his review, whether or not other colleges that are involved in this industry are using loopholes in the act to secure insurance through not being part of the Tertiary Assurance Scheme, and are being refused payment when they collapse because they have been engaged in fraudulent activity, such as the over-enrolment of students. We saw that, for instance, in the case that emerged last November of the International Business College, operating out of Sydney.

In Victoria we have a government currently facing an election. It claims that it is prepared to defend high quality educational outcomes, but it would seem that the operations of this act are unable to ensure that there are proper quality provisions. It is quite apparent that the Commonwealth government is not prepared to follow through its responsibilities to ensure that there are appropriate records kept and that there is proper monitoring undertaken to protect the quality assurance of Australian industry.

I repeat that it is my intention to pursue these questions through the parliamentary processes, and to ensure that we protect the quality of Australian education industry. I am afraid that I cannot say that there is the same level of scrutiny being provided by this government, and this minister in particular. I am particularly concerned about the operations of these so-called visa factories. I am concerned that the minister has not done all that he can to ensure that there is effective monitoring and coordination in government. If this government were serious about its whole-of-government approach, then we would see far greater actions taken to protect students and to protect the reputation of Australia in this area.

I am afraid that most people cannot rely upon the bland and glib assurances that are issued by this government as to reviews that are being undertaken when, quite clearly, there is an overwhelming body of evidence of inappropriate behaviour. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to speak today on a matter of public interest for people of the Gold Coast in my home state, Queensland, concerning a proposed development in the Runaway Bay part of the city of the Gold Coast. There is an article on the front page of a Gold Coast newspaper today about a proposed development for a sporting facility. It is being funded by a company and the profits from it are apparently going to go to sick children. A Gold Coast councillor, Alan Rickard, is quoted as saying:

speech.para: Here we have a major international benefactor who is investing a significant amount of money and not seeking any return.
They are just going to set this up, stand to one side and just feel glad to be involved. It is unheard of.

Councillor Rickard admits this is unusual but obviously thinks it is a good thing. On the surface, of course, it sounds like a good thingâa sporting facility, profits going to sick children. How can anyone object to that?

It is interesting that the article which talks about this facility going ahead appears before the facility has actually been given approval by the council. Indeed, it appears just a few days after a number of articles in the Gold Coast Bulletin outlining very significant concerns about the state of the site that the proposed development is meant to be going on. So there are many unusual things about this proposed development of a sporting facility, and it is not just a matter of an unusual degree of benevolence and philanthropy on the part of an international benefactor.

For a start, the area that the proposed development is going on was a toxic dump for a significant number of years. It was one of the three major liquid waste dumping sites in south-east Queensland. From 1939, for many years, for only a few dollars a truckload of liquid waste of various types could be dumped there with virtually no checking of the contents of that waste. The landfill site over a number of hectares included 15 raw sewage lagoons and, at one time, a hospital waste incinerator; there were grease traps; pathological waste from veterinarians, including carcasses, was dumped there; nightsoil was dumped there and also commercial industrial wasteâvirtually the whole gamut of waste.

People from south-east Queensland and the Brisbane area would probably be familiar with the Willawong site, which was also a toxic waste facility. It charged much higher prices than the Gold Coast site for the dumping of waste and certainly some degree at least, in the later years particularly, of oversight of what was actually put into it occurredâmuch greater stringency, it would appear, than was the case with this site on the Gold Coast. Yet, again as people from south-east Queensland would be aware, the costs and the necessary actions to clean up the Willawong site have been significant. There has been virtually none of that occurring on this old toxic dump site on the Gold Coast.

The former dump site is quite close to a canal estate in the area, and the canal flows through from there into the Broadwater. Recently, a marine biologist who has tested in the area, Dr Bob Morris, said that the former dump site is leaching toxic metals into the environment and posing a public health risk. Dr Morris has said:

My data strongly suggests that high levels of some highly toxic metals and organisms are coming from a point source in the vicinity of the old dump site. The levels of some of the toxic metals were much higher than I have ever previously encountered.

I should emphasise that Dr Morris, whom I have met, is a highly qualified practitioner. He is employed by the British government in assessing environmentally degraded sites along the coast of Britain and has a high degree of knowledge of the geological and pollution issues relating to acid sulfate soils and coastal development, and identifying the degrees of degradation and pollution. Certainly from my experience with him, I would say he is someone that, firstly, knows his stuff and, secondly, does not go round idly making wild accusations.

Dr Morris has been quoted as saying that oysters from a canal close to the old site had the highest pollution levels he has ever seen, and he has written to the Gold Coast Council asking for public warning signs to be erected in these canals. This is someone who has done a lot of testing in Europe and Britain and I think it would be pretty fair to say, without casting too many aspersions, that there are a few sites in those parts of the world that are not exactly pristine. For him to say these are the highest pollution levels he has ever seen in seafood is a matter of great concern.

This is only the latest in a long line of allegations, unfortunately, levelled at the former dump site. Of concern to me and to many people in the local community is the unavoidable reality that any development on the proposed site which was part of where the dump was would obviously dramatically affect rehabilitation. But, unusually, the council have rejected all of these concerns and seem to have been saying to date that their own studies give the area the all clear. Indeed, they are very keenly rushing forward to sign a lease to build a multimillion dollar sporting development on top of parts of this siteâa private development on public land designated recreational open space which used to be part of a major liquid waste dump. This is a matter of great concern to many people in the area.

There have been a number of decisions about granting development approval for this site which have occurred since 1995 and tomorrow the council is proposing to ratify a 50-year lease for eight hectares of the dump planned. The proposed developer is the US based InterPacific Resorts Pty Ltd.

The same consultants who examined the contamination of the site, testing and developing the site management plan, were used by the state government, the council, and by InterPacific Resorts. This, it seems to me, is a bit unusual. Normally, one would think independent consultants would work for each party separately in managing and testing contaminated land. The test results from the consultants which gave the area the all clear are in dispute, with scientists questioning the techniques, the location of test sites, and the analysis of results. A number of details of this have appeared in the Gold Coast Bulletin in recent times.

In 1997, the council conducted a drain clearing excavation for which, again unusually, they got state government approval retrospectively. Thanks to the drain clearing excavation, leachate was deliberately discharged into the ground water. Of course, some testing is now occurring on the nice capping layer of clean fill over the top. As anybody would know, putting a bit of clean fill over the top really has as much effect as sweeping dirt under the carpetâit certainly does not make it go away and it does not solve the problem.

This is an uncontrolled, unlined, former landfill site. That means there are no impervi ous barriers preventing intermingling with the ground water. The Queensland government and the Gold Coast City Council to date have refused to let an independent scientific body test the area. That seems unusual as well.

There are a number of other unusual things. The newspaper reports again detail how the site at one stage was valued at more than $4 million, a year later was revalued at $2 million, and later down to $300,000, and only after that valuation was the development approved. Unusually, the lease is costing less than $10,000 a year, and a 50-year lease has been provided rather than the usual 30-year one. InterPacific Resorts has also been handed a sole supplier status over the land which, again, seems somewhat unusual. They have also had sewerage connection charges waived, another unusual decision which I am told the council made against the advice of its own planning department.

Despite all this apparently somewhat unusual assistance to InterPacific Resorts, it turns out that InterPacific Resorts, which is funding the development, is allegedly not actually on the lease. It is intended that the site be leased by the Couran Cove Resort Children in Need Beneficiary Trust, the trustee of which is another company. The beneficiary trust will be administered by a small board of three people, including the head of the Couran Cove Resort on South Stradbroke Island. The concern is that the trust will then sublease the site to a construction company that would sign a management agreement with yet another company part owned by Mr Clarke, the person who heads the Couran Cove Resort on South Stradbroke Island.

According to media reports, another member of the three-member board administering the trust will probably be the aforementioned Gold Coast Councillor, Alan Rickard, whom I quoted at the start of my speech and who had such effusive praise for the project. This leaves the possibility that InterPacific Resorts can withdraw and leave a trust in place, a trust which would have no ability to address past, present or future contamination litigation issues. It is quite easy to see the potential for litigation down the track if the toxic nature of the old dump site is anywhere near as severe as many people are concerned it is.

It is not simply a matter of the health aspects of people using the facility that is going to be built on the site, but of people who use the canals and waterways surrounding the site for recreational purposes. It leaves a great concern that the health of future users of those facilities may be affected by some of these measures. It is better to ensure that everything is addressed beforehand, rather than have problems appear down the track, particularly ones that appear as probable as these ones.

The Runaway Bay Centre has refused to pay a bond to ensure the site is properly capped. The council has agreed to contribute $150,000 to the estimated capping cost of $1 million. This is a deal that the state government, business and the Gold Coast City Council have all been involved in and yet the risk is, in the end, that no-one will be liable, no-one will pick up the tab for cleaning up this site and any potential pollution that happens as a result of it.

It is a concern that the Gold Coast City Council appears to be refusing to allow independent scientific testing of the toxicity of the site before going ahead with considering approval. It is a concern that developers are hiding behind the Children in Need Beneficiary Trust. Everybody, of course, likes the idea of assistance going to children in need and charitable assistance being provided, but to refuse to address the genuine concerns that people have and use the screen of the need to support a so-called charitable development is something that I believe is inappropriate.

It is clear that mistakes have been made in the past. Untreated waste should never have been dumped there. Legal and transparent development approval processes should have been followed, and this site, clearly, should have been rehabilitated properly. Clearly, it has not.

This is not an isolated example. In Queensland, significant inquiries have been documented into illegal dumping of materials in recent years. Unfortunately, mistakes have been made in the past and, clearly, standards were not what they should have been. But there is not much point being aware of mistakes of the past unless you learn from them and seek to remedy them rather than cover them up, hoping nobody notices and pressing on regardless. I very much urge the Gold Coast City Council, and the trust which seems to be connected to it, that, when they decide whether or not they will ratify the decision to lease the site to a management chain of companies, they do not make another mistake by building on the ones of the pastâthat they stop the chain of mistakes and cover-ups over the years and they seek to get the facts about the state of the site at the moment and the potential implications on people who may use the site, or the canals and the waterways around the site, rather than blithely saying there is no problem, there is no concern and everything should go ahead.

It is a crucial test in many ways. This is a very significant site, and it is an opportunity for a very sizeable city council in Queensland to demonstrate that it is willing to bite the bullet and tackle some difficult issues, to pay attention to community concern, to ensure that there are not any unaddressed and unforeseen potential future problems, and to recognise as a council their responsibilities and liabilities for public health of their residents and of those who use the area. I do urge them very much to take that responsibility seriously. It is certainly a decision that many people, including me, will be watching closely. It is not just a matter of one small development on one block; it is a matter of potential consequences and ongoing implications for waterways surrounding that area. That is something that I believe people not just at local council level but more broadly need to ensure that there is proper monitoring of and, if proper monitoring is not occurring through the council, then perhaps other bodies will need to take a closer interest in it.

talk.start.para: âIn my contribution to the MPI debate today, I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate the ongoing plight of regional Australia and the policy issues it raises. It came home very strongly to me last year when I was moving through the New England region of New South Wales, through what is called big sky country. As part of the highway that leads from Tenterfield down to Armidale, there is a major railway that runs beside the New England Highway. This was shut down about 25 years ago. For 75 kilometres there are weeds growing through the railway line and there are old broken-down stations. Perhaps to add insult to injury over the years, the New England Highway has been realigned across part of this old rail, putting us in a situation where the line could probably never be re-opened again.

speech.para: This used to be a very vital lifeline into other areas of New South Wales that is now no longer there. The result of this type of withdrawal of services has been creating great problems across the bush for many decades. There has been a tension between the city and the bush that has existed for a long time. It is perhaps best highlighted by A.D. Hope in a poem in 1938, when he described the major cities of Australia:
And her five cities, like five teeming sores, each drains her vast parasite robber state.

Since that time we have had further decline in population and in a number of key industries in the bush. If you have a look at the statistics, eight years after A.D. Hope's words, 38 per cent of the population was outside the capital cities at that point. By 1998 it had dropped to 28 per cent, and it continues to decline.

The big challenge in rural and regional Australia, particularly given the opening up of the economyâthe moves towards deregulation and globalisationâis to come up with effective strategies to assist the bush to survive in this new global environment. Just as a cameo, something happened at lunchtime that illustrates one of those survival strategies. I was at the launch of the Telstra Big Pond advance system, where, by satellite into rural and regional Australia, the Internet will have a capacity of 400 kilobytes per second compared with the current capacity of 64. In that way, the bush is tending to leapfrog.

In the areas of information technology and a whole range of new strategies there is a lot of hope for the bush, but over the years a number of strategies have not worked. We need to evaluate the approach we are taking now and see how we can provide government support with policy for the development of our rural and regional areas. Historically, back in the 1950s and 1960s we had departments of decentralisation. We tended to foster outside the capital cities a cargo cult mentality that we would be able to get industries to move out of the cities into the bush, a mentality of, `If only this particular industry would come to our town, that would solve our problems.' There was not any great exodus of manufacturing from the cities to the bush at that time, and there was not a great eagerness to take up the more low-cost environment that existed then, so the policy of the 1950s and 1960s did not work.

Moving to the 1970s, Gough Whitlam came up with a regional growth centre strategy which perhaps had its best expression in an area like Albury-Wodonga. In the Bathurst-Orange area, a new city of Victoria was planned. Both of those experiments failed. The story goes that Gough came up with the policy in the early 1970s. He was looking for a policy for southern New South Wales. He found that the Riverina had a dam and it had a college of advanced education. What on earth could he promise them? He came up with this Albury-Wodonga growth centre concept, which has now been wound down. We now have the situation where Victoria is occupied by possums and wombats. That failed experiment is now where we are up to in the story that I am putting before the Senate about changing policy. We are about to get to question time, so I am running out of time. I will continue at the next MPI.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard

talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

âNo, you haven't.
âWhere is theâ
âAren't you too precious!
âI certainly would not want to be accused of being precious in the way you were for years.

âWe have already dealt with these matters. But I think probably the most important thing that has emerged in terms of what is newâas opposed to recycled matters some days oldâis a document called `The 16 shonks tipping competition'. Instructions: tick the 16 Federation Fund projects from the list which you think came fromâ

âI cannot direct the minister to answer the question. He must be relevant to the matter that has been raised. I would ask Senator Alston to proceed, but having the question in mind.

answer.para: I do not know what this `16 shonks tipping competition'âa fax from the office of John Faulknerâis meant to be. One has to presume that this is just a sick joke to fill in time because there is nothing much else happening in opposition. It says:

This puts it in context, Madam President. This has now become a little joke for insiders. This is not a serious policy issue at all. What Senator Faulkner has done is demonstrate to the public at large that this is really a game that is being played.

Until today, of course, we did not know the extent to which they thought this was a joke, but we now do. talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

âThank you, Madam President. We have made it very plain that we are not in the business of putting numbers alongside these projects, either by money or by points.
