âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Will the minister inform the Senate of the major gains for Australian workers and families achieved as a result of the government's sound economic policies? Is the minister aware of recent reports by commentators which underline the success of the government's strategy?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Chapman for this important question. Senator Chapman has shown a long interest in policies relating to the economy and has made a great contribution over the years. I welcome the question from Senator Chapman.

answer.para: The government is very proud of its achievements in relation to the economy and in relation to the benefits that have been provided to Australian workers and families. These benefits can be summed up briefly as more jobs, better pay, lower mortgage costs, and, of course, major tax cuts on the way. These have all been delivered in the context of Australia's very strong economy, which I think is the envy of the region and possibly the world.

We are very proud of our record on jobs. There are more people in employment now than at any other time in Australian history. Almost half a million new jobs have been created in the 3Â½ years since this government has been in office. Jobs growth has translated into lower unemployment. Australia's unemployment rate this July of seven per cent is the lowest since July 1990. Not only are there more jobs but also wages are increasing faster than inflation, meaning that more workers are getting ahead. This reflects the very strong productivity performance of the Australian economy in recent years.

Not only are there more jobs, not only are real wages higher, but also home mortgage rates have fallen very substantially. When Labor lost officeâthe unlamented Labor governmentâhome mortgage rates were at 10.5 per cent. And we all remember when home mortgage rates were at an incredible 17 per cent during the term of the Labor government. Basic home mortgage rates are now in the order of six to 6.5 per cent and these are delivering very substantial savings in payments of interest by Australian families. And the good news does not stop there. We are delivering, as a result of the tax reform package, the largest tax cuts in Australian historyâtax cuts of the order of $12 billion on income tax paid by Australian families.

More jobs, lower taxes, lower interest ratesâthis is a great record of achievement, and I am very pleased to say that other commentators have noticed that. Many in the Senate will remember former Senator Richardson, a former powerbroker of the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âWho?

âHe is recalled with varying degrees of affection in this chamber. Senator Faulkner has one particular view of the former senator, and others have other views. But this is what this former Labor powerbroker said on the record of the Howard government: `The Howard government has had some major success on the economic front and that ought to be acknowledged.' This is what he went on to say and I think it is worth recording. If I had a supplementary I could go on. (Time expired)

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask the Assistant Treasurer if he would enlighten us on any recent reports by commentators. I note that he had started to do that, and I would appreciate additional information on the opinions expressed by those commentators.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThank you, Senator Chapman. That is a very good supplementary, I might say, which shows a great quickness of mind. Former Senator Richardson said, `If there is one thing that flourished under the Labor government, it was unemployment.' This former Labor powerbroker has acknowledged the success of this government in managing the economy. He has recognised the problems which occurred under the previous governmentâas indeed people like Mr Graham Campbell have recognised a fall real wages. We have a very proud record of achievement, and that is why I believe that the Labor Party, in its policy-free zone, will be out of office and over that side of the parliament for a very long period of time.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. How does the minister justify agreeing to an independent departmental task force to assess applications under the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program, endorsing a detailed and rigorous assessment process as he did on 9 July last year, asserting that this process accorded with the Auditor-General's guidelines, and then dismissing the outcome of this process as `arbitrary and gratuitous', as he did yesterday? talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am very sorry that Senator Evans was not here for the whole of question time yesterday because had he been he would have heard me explain in excruciating detail that we took the view that we should look at all these projects. We did not want to take the easy way out and simply look at the 114, or do what Senator Faulkner would have done and rung up the Secretary of the department and said, `For heaven's sake, we have only got to select 60; send us 62.' We actually wanted to look at the lot. In order to do that, we looked at every project. What I was saying yesterday was that the department took it upon themselves to draw a line for convenienceâgratuitous, because they were not asked to draw a line, and they understand that.
â`Took it upon themselves'! You agreed to the process beforehand. You signed up to the process.
âOrder! Senator Conroy, shouting across the chamber in that fashion is totally disorderly. It is not your question, in any event.

The fact is that we were given advice by the joint task forceâ

âSenator Conroy, I have already called you to order.

âMadam President, I presume Senator Conroy is interested to know that in Deakin the Labor councillor Nick Kermos actually thanked the government and told the Liberal member he was most appreciative of such a worthwhile project. âName them.
âWell, you've blown your cover.
âName the 16 shonks.
âNo, you are inviting your colleaguesâ
âOrder!

âThis is the whole point, Madam President. What Senator Faulkner is effectively saying is: `I know you blokes have got nothing else better to do with your time'. answer.para: These things are presumably going to be pinned up on the walls in the caucus room and everyone is going to have a bit of a giggle and say, `Really and truly, we have managed to get through the last fortnight with absolutely nothing going for us. Once again we have avoided tackling any serious policy issues. We have played these little games. We thought that we could project a serious face.' And look at Senator Faulknerâhe is smirking even now. They can't help themselves. He has blown his own cover. You should have waited and sent this out in the dead of night. Instead of faxing it across to meâI do not need to see this rubbish; I have better things to do with my timeâyou should hand deliver it if you are worried about security. We can give you some decent encryption systems that will make sure this sort of thing does not happen again. All I can say is that we are very grateful to Senator FaulknerâI am sure his colleagues are notâfor really putting it on the table once and for all that this is a silly little game that has really backfired.

talk.start.para: âI have a supplementary question. I must agree with the minister: his answers are excruciating. Is he further aware that the Auditor-General has stated that `accurate and relevant information explaining the reasons for decisions is the key to effective accountability because it enables the public to make informed decisions about the performance of officials'? How can his refusal to publicly release the reasons for his decisions be consistent with those guidelines? If the minister is so confident that his judgment was so superior to that of the independent departmental task force, why won't he release the reasons for his decisions?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI would have thought minimum standards of literacy should be expected in this chamber. We have had the sort of tautology paraded that says `guidelines require', when everyone knows by definition guidelines do not require; they provide advice. I have had some legal advice on this issue and the position is quite clear. The Auditor-General's view is that we should comply with the requirements of the FOI Act. That act contains certain exemptions, like internal working documents, like business services. In other words, you comply with it to the extent that you are required to by the act.

answer.para: This was handled in the departmentâno interference by us. An independent decision is made and who didn't bother to appeal when he got knocked back? It just shows you. Couldn't he afford the $30? He could not even have asked for a remittance of it. He did not bother going ahead because he did not want to turn up at the AAT and get rolled. talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. The Minister for Finance and Administration recently announced the results of the pre-registration of Telstra 2. Minister, what has been the response of the Australian public to this new share offer and what does the further privatisation of Telstra mean to ordinary Australians?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âThis is more good news for Australia and I thank Senator Tierney for this very important question. Some 1.8 million Australians have reserved purchases for these shares in Telstra that we have recently announced. That is in addition to the 1.3 million existing Telstra shareholders. So we now have 3.1 million Australians, a quarter of all adult Australians, involved in this great process.

âIt is worth taking note of an aspect that Senator Forshaw might want to listen to. Some 10 per cent of those people seeking to own Telstra shares did so through the Internet for their pre-registration. Telstra finds itself in this new world of technology. It is great that people are using the Internet to avail themselves of this offer.

answer.para: What we are doing in this offer is bringing new people into ownership of shares, but we are also rewarding those people who took the plunge and already have Telstra shares. We will be offering a purchase of one share for five shares already held. If you have 3,000 Telstra shares, you will be able to purchase another 600. That is great news for people who already hold shares. But there is more to it than just that. In this Telstra 2 we have a new streamlined way of dealing with our bankers and the commission fees. Instead of the 23 bankers and brokers we dealt with previously, we are now dealing with 17. That has resulted in a $25 million saving in commissions.

Senator Tierney mentioned the benefits for ordinary Australians. This government has a basic policy regarding the dream that the people of Australia have not only of ownership of a home but ownership of sharesâparticipating in the ownership of a great company like Telstra. Another aspect to the privatisation of Telstra is the benefit to the Australian community as a whole. It will allow us to reduce debt. Earlier, we heard from Senator Kemp about how strongly the economy is going under the Howard government. The sale of Telstra will help us to pay off debt, to do away with interest payments which are a liability to the national economy.

Not only will the 3.1 million Australians who already have an interest in Telstra benefit, but all Australians will benefit from the sale of Telstra because we will be able to keep interest rates low and look at tax cuts which will benefit the average Australian working man and woman. We will be able to use that money for infrastructure in rural and regional Australia, which can only be good news for this country. This is great news for Australiaânot only for those people who are interested in owning shares but for the wider community.

Of course, the opposition and those who are against the sale of Telstra fail to realise this. I say to senators who are against a further sale of Telstra: wake up and take notice of the benefits for all Australia which are contained in the privatisation of Telstra. Look at what we are offering average men and womenâ3.1 million people, a quarter of all Australian adults, may soon own Telstra shares, and some members of the opposition have also been involved.

talk.start.para: âSensible ones.

â`Sensible ones', says Senator Macdonald. We are saying, think of the wider benefits for Australia and the national economy and the strengths which we are enjoying at the moment, which Senator Kemp referred to earlier. Let us keep Australia going forward and let us push forward the privatisation of Telstra.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Can the minister confirm the information he provided at estimates that final decisions on federation cultural and heritage projects were taken at a meeting between him and Senator Hill on or about 27 August last year, that no departmental officials were present, that there was no departmental note taker and that staffers made, as he put it to Fran Kelly this morning, `sufficient record to provide reasons for the decisions'? What form did the `sufficient record' take? Is it maintained in the minister's office or the department? Is it available for examination by the Auditor-General?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI thought we had gone over this ground many times before as well.
âWe haven't.

âHaven't we. Then let us go back to the beginning and explain how the process worked. It was not up to the department to make final decisions. The department was there to provide ratings. They put numbers alongside projects and the joint task force, comprised of officials from both my department and from Senator Hill's department, provided that advice. We also had advice from the National Council for the Centenary of Federation. From that point on, there was no involvement required or expected of the department or indeed of anyone else from the outside who might have wanted to offer advice, gratuitous or otherwise. It follows that it would have been quite superfluous for officials of the department to have been present when we were making decisions.

answer.para: We did in fact provide written reasons for our decisions, which are contained in the material which was the subject of Senator Faulkner's FOI request. I find it rather surprising that he bothered to go to the trouble of submitting an application under the FOI Act, presumably becauseâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam President: the minister is not attempting to answer the question I asked. I asked what form the so-called `sufficient record' took; I asked whether it was maintained in the minister's office or the department; and I asked whether it was available for examination by the Auditor-General. I did not ask for Senator Alston's comments on the other extraneous matters, inaccurate as they might be. It is an important question that goes to accountability and transparency and I ask you to direct the minister to answer it.

âOn the point of order, Madam President: I do not know how many times Senator Faulkner has taken this type of point of order when the minister answering the question has had only a minute out of four minutes to answer. It is an abuse of process to consistently interrupt ministers with a point of order when we know what you are going to say. You cannot direct the minister as to how to answer the question. To say that he has not answered it when he has had only one quarter of the time available to him is clearly an abuse of process and should not be allowed to continue.
âThere is no point of order. The minister is dealing with the issue that has been raised and has time to continue to do so.

âThank you, Madam President. It is also significant that in that long recital of what Senator Faulkner thinks should be responded to he omitted to mention the fact that he had asked me whether departmental officials were present. Of course, I was in the process of explaining that there was no need for them to be present.

answer.para: The reality is that Senator Faulkner has been caught short. He is excruciatingly embarrassed by the fact that it is now plain to all the world that the Labor Party regards this as a bit of an in-house joke. This is no longer a serious policy issue and if you did not need the 16 tipping shonks competition forms to know that, you only have to look at the approach taken under FOI.

Senator Faulkner asked what record was keptâpresumably the reasons for the decisionâand, once again, I was in the process of explaining that there was a record. That is the very thing that Senator Faulkner sought to obtain under freedom of information. But, of course, he has a very short concentration span. Having been knocked back, he did not bother appealing. In other words, he did not pursue his legal rights. He was not interested in due process. He decided, presumably, that this was just something that ought to be kicked around in the public arenaâit was a political issue, not a legal issueâand that is how it was going to be played. That is how it has been played out ever since. Apart from getting someone on the Sydney Morning Herald to give this a bit of a kick along every so often, it was exposed long ago as having no legs. I am waiting for Senator Faulkner to invite me to table the document because I did read from it very carefully. I would be more than happy to accommodate him if he sought that. That very document says it all. This is not a serious policy issue; this is a tipping contest; this is a game to be played by those who have no policy ideas.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in relation to the meeting between yourself and Minister Hill on 27 August last year, how was the record kept of decisions taken at the meeting? How was the record kept? What form did that record of decisions take? Is it maintained in the minister's office or in the department? Is it available for examination by the Auditor-General?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI note that Senator Faulkner forgot to ask me to table the document. I will overlook that lapse of memory. He did claim the other day that he was interested in due process. That is really what this whole issue is about: were records kept; were they provided; are they accessible to the Auditor-General; are they available under FOI, subject to the exemptions provided in the legislation? Beyond that, of course Senator Faulkner is entitled to have a goâif he wants to try and get a bit more minutiae, if he wants to put it on the table and have a bit more of a run.
âWhy don't you answer the question?
âIf you do not think it is relevant, I will not bother.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to his decision yesterday to allow Telstra to charge for directory assistance calls from mobile and business phone users. I ask the minister: what will this cost small business, and how long will it be before the government allows Telstra to charge residential users for 013 calls?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to get a serious policy question. The answer is that the majority of small businesses will pay around 40c per month. The reason it is important that this initiative be pursued is that some large businesses were making hundreds of calls a day on the 013 line. In fact, nine of them were making more than 200 calls a day. One small business was recorded as making 1,730 calls per month to directory assistance, while there were 11 other small business users making over 200 free calls per monthâlike call centres.
âMaybe they needed assistance.

âYes, like debt collectors. They need all the help they can get, don't they? Call centres, finance companies, auction housesâthese are businesses that basically build it into their business plan. The fact that this service has been free until now is something that businesses, which can well afford to pay for it, were simply taking advantage of, to the detriment of many other callers. In fact, more than 50 per cent of mobile subscribers already pay directory assistance charges because they are either Optus or Vodaphone subscribers. They charge 40c. It seems only reasonable to me that Telstra should do the same.

answer.para: Small businesses will not be disadvantaged in any shape or form. Six out of 10 small business lines made no calls to directory assistance over the two-month period April to May this year, which was the period of the sample. Of those who used directory assistance, 64 per cent made fewer than three calls per month; seven per cent made over 10 calls per month and accounted for 54 per cent of calls by small business to directory assistance. Most importantly, 48 per cent of small businesses are connected to the Internet. So they have the capacity to go online and access White Pages without any additional charge. I think it is perfectly plain that this is a reform that was long overdue. I was particularly interested to see that the shadow minister did not rule out the Labor Party doing precisely the same thing in their next term of government. Had we not done it, Labor clearly would have.

There is all the difference in the world between charging businesses and mobile users and residential customers. Almost all businesses and mobile users, by definition, can afford to pay. We have excluded the disabled, the not-for-profit organisations, the charities and the payphones; in other words, all those who deserve special consideration. I would have thought that most mobile phone users probably do not even realise that it has been a free service until now. There is all the difference in the world between businesses and mobile users and residential.

We would take a very different approach if and when we were ever asked to consider the matter. We have not. But the minister of the day has a legal obligation to consider matters that are put before him. All I can say is that that is not on the agenda. It is certainly not, in any shape or form, under consideration, and I have no reason to think that it ever will be. Certainly, I think this is a reform that took a bit of political courageânot much. Nonetheless, it is something that the Labor Party could have done in 13 years but simply never got around to doing. It is a sensible reform. It will ensure that we come into line with other telcos overseas. We have some important trade-offs. Now 70 per cent of calls will be answered within 10 seconds as a matter of commitment, which I think is very important.

talk.start.para: âWhen will we see that?
âYou will see that. In fact, you will hear it if you tune in. (Time expired)

âI ask a supplementary question. Again I ask the minister about residential users on 013. Can he categorically assure the Senate that these will not be charged? Further, the minister's press release says that all phone users contribute to subsidising the directory assistance service. If this is the case, how much does the minister expect other charges to fall as a result of the charges being applied to 013 calls?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThis is simply part of the business mix. If Telstra makes more money from one area rather than another, it has the capacity to reduce prices in a whole range of areas. Does Senator Allison think we are going to get out there and tell Telstra that they should bring down prices in one particular area just because they have at long last been able to recoup the cost of these services? Bear in mind that residential users take up about 46 per cent of the calls. There are currently 440 million calls a year to directory assistance. That number has gone up 40 million in the last 12 months. So it is a very significant impost on Telstra. It does not provide them with any incentive at all to make that service efficient. However, once you make it a commercial activity, you encourage others to come into the business. That will hopefully bring down prices of this very service, as has happened with people like scoop.com in the UK and as I am sure will happen elsewhere. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. The minister has claimed that he and Senator Hill examined all the applications that were submitted on the FCHP, not just the 114 above 15 points. Does he also claim that that is a sufficient recordâto use his wordsâof the process? He claims a sufficient record of the process was maintained. I ask: does a record in fact exist? In what form does it exist? Is it written? Is it electronic? Is it on the back of a beer coaster? Is the record in existence and is it available to the Auditor-General?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI can assure Senator Faulkner of one thing: it is not written on the back of a tipping competition form. There is an extraordinary non sequitur in that question. The proposition was that Senator Hill and I claim to have examined all the eligible projects, not just the 114. Is there a record? Is there a sufficient record? All I can say is that examinations of documents are usually visual. So to ask me whether there is a record of us visually examining is presumably asking me whether we had a camera present. I do not remember any of the networks being invited and I certainly do not remember anyone in the room thinking it was such an important occasion that it deserved to be memorialised for all time. If we had known that there was going to be a tipping competition and there might be some prizes handed out, maybeâand this is only with the benefit of hindsightâwe could perhaps have arranged for a photographer to be present. Unfortunately, we did not. All I can say is that you will just have to take my word for it that Senator Hill and I actually did our homework. We did look at a whole range of projectsâwell beyond the call of duty, I might say. If the real issue is who examined the projects, I want to know when you are going to get out there, get on shanks's pony and have a look at some of these projects. See what you think of them. You could actually have a bit of a guide on the tipping sheet. You could give them an indicative view of whether you think they stack up or not. You could look at the electorates that you do not like and mark them down and you could look at a few of your preferred marginals and tick them up. But the fact is you are not prepared to do your homework, are you? Madam President, they are simply not interested.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Carr, you are persistently interjecting.

âI hope Senator Carr has taken my advice from yesterday. He only has 24 days to go. I am sure that Mr Bracks would very much appreciate him staying in Canberra for the duration. Apart from Senator Carr having to stay here, there is no good reason why the rest of that crowd over there cannot get out and go and visit some of these projects. I am sure they will find all the councils very happy to take them around. You will probably find the local members, including the Labor members, particularly thrilled to explain the virtues of these projects. It is not a big ask, really, is it? You do not have to do much more than make a phone call. When you are working out how to fill in the next couple of weeks with nothing much on the program and none of the interest groups wanting to see you any more because you have nothing to offerâ
âSenator Alston, you are straying from the question.
âThat is probably true, Madam President.

âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I will not take the minister's word for it. Neither, do I suspect, will the parliament or the public. So I ask: what sufficient recordâto use the minister's wordsâwas taken? How was that record taken? What form was it kept in? Who took the record, Minister? Is that record available for examination by the Auditor-General?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âIt is getting very, very repetitive, isn't it? I thought I had explained, in tedious detail, that if the question was, `Is there a record of Senator Hill and me examining the projects?' then I suppose we could ask our staff whether they have a vivid recollection of watching Senator Hill. Maybe some of them were looking over his shoulder.
âSo it's memory now, is it?

âThat is not really the point at issue. The point is whether we did in fact examine projects, whether we did make judgments and whether we provided decisions and reasons for them. And we did all of the above.

âMy question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the work of Dr Joel Brind, Professor of Human Biology and Endocrinology at Baruch College, City University, New York and an international authority on the link between abortion and increased risk of breast cancer? Is the minister aware of the epidemiological and biological evidence of such a link? Have the minister and his department considered the serious implications of this for public health policy and practice, and the possible future legal action by women for whom the risk was not disclosed? What are the minister and the department doing to ensure women are fully informed of the potential risk? Has the minister considered adding reproductive history to the current breast screening mammogram survey, using a coded recorded linked process to maintain privacy, so as to obtain a fuller picture of a possible connection and the need for provision of information to potentially at-risk women?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Harradine for the question; it is a very serious question. The minister advises that there is no consistent evidence that demonstrates a direct relationship between breast cancer and either induced or spontaneous abortion. Expert advice indicates that almost all the studies on induced abortion and risk of breast cancer are case controlled studies which have produced conflicting results. Many of the articles that support a link are old, and more recent articles question the methodologies employed in these studies. More recent studies indicate little support for the hypothesis that induced abortion increases breast cancer risk overall or in particular subgroups. Michaels and Willett in Epidemiology September 1996 reviewed evidence to better understand the apparent inconsistencies and concluded:

answer.para: Studies to date are inadequate to infer with confidence the relation between induced or spontaneous abortion and breast cancer risk, but it appears that any such relation is likely to be small or non-existent.

The government provides funding to the BreastScreen Australia program to reduce mortality and morbidity from breast cancer through early detection. It also provides funding to the National Breast Cancer Centre. The National Breast Cancer Centre has recently conducted a review of the data on induced abortion and increased risk of breast cancer, and the National Breast Cancer Centre's view is that a causal association between induced abortion and breast cancer has not yet been established. In the event that new research on this issue emerges, the National Breast Cancer Centre will analyse it and make the findings readily available to women and health professionals as part of its ongoing role.

The women's longitudinal study being conducted through Newcastle University and funded by the Commonwealth is another source of data on the possible link between induced abortion and breast cancer in the medium to long term. The study involves over 40,000 Australian women and it will explore a range of health and health related issues. This study is designed to follow young, middle-aged and older women for up to 20 years and will address gaps in knowledge about women's health.

Senator Harradine has suggested that BreastScreen Australia ask women to provide details of their reproductive history. The feasibility of this idea will be considered by the National Advisory Committee for BreastScreen Australia. This committee provides policy advice to the Commonwealth and state and territory health ministers on BreastScreen Australia. In considering this issue the committee will need to consider the Privacy Act 1998 and the information privacy principles which govern the collection of personal data within government programs. Under these principles, information on a woman's reproductive history could only be collected if that information is considered directly related to the purpose of the BreastScreen Australia program. I have already mentioned one of the references in Epidemiology September 1996; there are other references that I could refer Senator Harradine to.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Does the minister stand by his statement yesterday:

question.para: Never at any stage was either department in the business of recommending or advising us on any particular project.

Further, why was this so and how was it made clear to the two departments that they were not to recommend or advise ministers on any particular project? If the departmental submission was neither recommendation nor advice, what was it?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI thought I had made it clear that the task of the joint task force was to provide points on a rating basis out of 24. Once that information was provided to ministers, it was then open to them to make up their own minds. By drawing a line under the 114 projects that rated 15 points or more, the departments were not advising or recommending; they were simply indicating that, in their view, that quantity provided a sufficient pool from which ministers could make their selection. It was perfectly proper for them to present the material in that way, but at the end of the day what we wanted was a point score for each project. We got that and we made our decisions accordingly.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that confirmation. Is the minister aware that one of the key criticisms that the Auditor-General made of the Community Facilities Program in 1993 was that the department did not make recommendations to the minister? Is the minister further aware that one of the recommendations of the House of Representatives committee report on the Auditor-General's efficiency audit of the Community Facilities Program, which had the full support of coalition members, was:

question.para: In all future grants . . . the Department . . . ought to provide a schedule of applications that evaluates the proposed projects and contains recommendations to guide the Minister's decisions.
I will repeat that for you, Minister:
. . . and contains recommendations to guide the Minister's decisions.
Minister, why were departmental recommendations so critical then, so fully supported by the coalition, but are so irrelevant now?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe question was: was I aware? The answer is no.

subdebateinfo.title: Industrial Relations: Junior Rates of Pay

talk.start.para: âMy question is also to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. In developing a legislative response to the AIRC junior rates report, will the government acknowledge, as the commission does, that age-based discrimination in determining wages is a serious issue and that a formal process for assessing discrimination will be needed in the Workplace Relations Act? Will the case by case assessments of junior rates be required to acknowledge that age-based discrimination is undesirable? And will Australia continue to share with the Nether lands the distinction of being virtually the only industrialised country to regard 19-, 20- and 21-year-old workers as juniors when it comes to pay rates, even though they are considered full adults for the purposes of most other legislation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think what Senator Stott Despoja is really asking me is: `Am I aware that at least sheâand maybe others of her colleaguesâtake the view that we should not be particularly concerned about maximising the employment opportunities of young people and about the fact that many young people and their parents take the view that junior wage rates are a very important means of providing those opportunities?' The amended billâI was going to say `which, to their credit, they support,' but they obviously looked at the opinion polls and decided they had no choiceâwhich the Labor Party are supporting, removes the threat to junior rates and to youth jobs that has existed since 1993. It achieves this by permanently exempting junior rates from the age discrimination requirements of the act. This will protect the jobs of more than 220,000 young people in the retail industry alone.

answer.para: I do not know whether Senator Stott Despoja says, `Well, that really does not matter. We are not concerned about protecting their jobs. We somehow think that discrimination is where it starts and finishes. As long as you are not being discriminated against, we really don't care if you've got all day sitting on the sidelines to celebrate the fact that you are unemployed but not discriminated against.' So the amended bill goes beyond just protecting junior rates; it introduces, for the first time in workplace relations laws, objects which require the AIRC to protect the competitive position of young people in the labour market, to promote youth employment and to assist in reducing youth unemployment. In exercising its award making and other functions the commission will be required to further these objects to the benefit of the employment prospects of young people.

Does Senator Stott Despoja disagree with any of that? Presumably she does, because she says, `Well, but that constitutes some form of discrimination. So I don't want the commission out there trying to provide them with jobs, because it might technically offend against some discrimination provision. I want their job prospects to depend entirely on whether they regard it themselvesâor someone else regards itâas discrimination.' That is not the basis on which the commission will operate. It is not the basis on which this law will operate. It is not the basis on which the major parties in this parliament believe the law should operate.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. While I appreciate the minister's rephrasing of my question, I would like to ask him again: will the government's legislative response to the AIRC's report involve a formal process for assessing discrimination in the Workplace Relations Act? Will the government also acknowledge, as the commission has done, that discrimination on the basis of age is a serious issue? I am wondering whether the minister has read the AIRC's report and whether he can acknowledge, for the benefit of the chamber, that that report does not unequivocally place a correlation between wage rates for juniors and employment prospects.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âYes, we do regard age discrimination as a serious issue. If people say, `You are performing brilliantly but you just happen to be over 65,' I do not think that is too fair. But if they say, `You're 17. You are doing a good job. We'd love to keep you on but you turn 18 next week. We have to pay you an extra 50 bucks and we cannot afford it,' I do not regard that as discrimination; I regard that as a rational response to the cost of labour.
âSack the young.
âYou take a different view, do you, Senator Cook? What is this expression? Sack the gun? Is this something they trot out in the trades hall council. It is a new one on me.

âI raise a point of order on relevance, Madam President. In the time remaining, would the minister answer at least one question, and that is: will a formal process for assessing discrimination be included in the act? How are you going to assess discrimination, Minister, and will you include it in the act? Perhaps he could answer one element of my question.
âThat is not a point of order.
âI will say it again. The bill achieves this protection of youth wages and jobs by permanently exempting junior rates from the age discrimination requirements of the Workplace Relations Act.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to his previous answers and the fact that both departments did not make recommendations in relation to projects to be funded under the $70 million Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program but presented ministers with a list of 114 projects which ranked 15 points or above, which ministers then chose to ignore in the case of 16 selections. Does the minister recall that in March 1994 his colleague Senator Hill asked the following question in relation to the $30 million Community, Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program:

question.para: Why was this program not determined and administered in the usual wayâthat is, by the department making recommendations on agreed guidelines? Why did the minister politicise the program in this way?
Would the minister care to answer the same question in respect of the FCHP program, for which he and his colleague Senator Hill have joint responsibility?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âOne, we were not provided simply with a list of 114 projects; we were provided with a list of a lot more than that. Did we choose to ignore what we were given? The answer is no. Do I recall Senator Hill asking a question in 1994? Many of them, but I do not think that one in particular.
âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did departments not make recommendations in relation to this program? Was it under instruction from ministers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âWe have been through this endlessly. I have stated the facts of the matter and I have nothing more to add.

âMy question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Is the minister aware of calls for the creation of a coastguard service in Australia? Can the minister inform the Senate what is the government's position in relation to the creation of a coastguard?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferguson for the question. Yes, Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, recently said on radio that Australia should have a coastguard. Madam President, you might be interested to know that he went on to say:

answer.para: The image that would come with a coastguard would be a very substantial upgrade ofâ
you really have to wait for thisâ
an appearance of preparedness.

All he wanted was an image of `appearance of preparedness'. The only thing of substance proposed was a `substantial upgrade of an appearance of preparedness'. His sentiments have been parroted by the shadow minister in the past.

Coastal surveillance is a serious issue and it has to be taken seriously. If you want to contribute to the policy debate in a considered and well thought out manner, well and good, but if you just want a few appearances you will be judged accordingly. In their enthusiasm to get a grab on radio, Mr Beazley and Mr Kerr seem to have forgotten the Beazley report. The Beazley report was done in March 1984. It was a review of Australia's peacetime coastal surveillance and protection arrangements. It was done by Kim C. Beazley, Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. Mr Beazley's own report makes it clear that a coastguard was not an efficient or a cost-effective option. Labor had 13 years in government and they did not establish a coastguard, because they knew, as the Beazley report made clear, that it was not an efficient or a cost-effective option. Now apparently they like the idea. They think it has got something going for it. This is a clear case of policy amnesia simply brought about by media starvation.

People smuggling is a growing global problem. Canada, for example, in recent weeks has had two boatloads of Chinese illegal immigrants: one boatload of 134 and one of 123. The United States Coastguard has an annual budget of $US4 billion, and they still find it necessary to operate in tandem with other agencies. They protect a coastline of about 20,000 kilometres in length compared to our 37,000 kilometres.

While the opposition sit there on the sideline carping away in their normal negative fashion to which we have become accustomed, the government has actually done something to properly handle the growing problem of people smuggling.
Senator Bolkus interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Bolkus.

âAustralia is currently negotiating three extra protocols to add to the transnational crime convention dealing with these matters. The Prime Minister's recent task force announcement pumped an extra $124 million into combating people smuggling. That is not an upgrade of appearance; it is an upgrade in substance. It includes two new Dash 8 aircraft with sophisticated electronic surveillance, a night capable helicopterâ

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Bolkus, you are persistently interjecting. I invite you to read standing order 203.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âYesterday Senator Woodley asked me why Ansett Australia had withdrawn from the aircraft study being done by the American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Airconditioning Engineers. I have an answer which I would like to read part of.

speech.para: Ansett have provided advice that they agreed to participate in that project believing that it was officially endorsed by the Federal Aviation Administration of the USA. Ansett subsequently learned that this was not the case. Ansett could not spare the aircraft operationally because their priority focus was modifying the BAe 146 aircraft fleet to overcome the odour problem for the benefit of customers and staff. Ansett's BAe 146 modification program is so advanced that their fleet is not representative of the world's BAe 146 population and therefore not appropriate for the study of the type that was proposed by that American society.

Ansett are one of 65 BAe 146 operators worldwide. It is true that Australia has a high number of reported problems, but Ansett inform me that that is because Ansett Australia is the only airline in the world that has a compulsory reporting program. I should also mention that, in a recent court hearing about Ansett's flight attendants' claims in relation to the BAe 146 fumes, the court accepted evidence that there was no toxicity in the fumes coming into the cabin. Ansett also advise me that they have demonstrated their complete commitment to corporate responsibility in this matter in ways unmatched by any other operator in Australia. In fairness to Ansett, I seek leave to incorporate the full text of the answer which they have given me.
Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
Question 1
Ansett Australia is one of 65 BAe 146 operators worldwide. Of those, five operate in Australia.

If it is true that Australia has the highest number of reported problems, it may be because of the number of BAe 146 aircraft operating in Australia and because one of those operators, Ansett Australia, is the only airline in the world that has a compulsory reporting program.
Question 2
Ansett Australia has withdrawn from participating in a study being done by the American Society of Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) for three reasons
1. Ansett agreed to participate in the project believing that it was officially endorsed by the Federal Aviation Administration of the USA Ansett subsequently learned that this is not the case
2. Ansett could not spare the aircraft operationally because its priority focus was modifying the BAe 146 fleet to overcome the odour problem for the benefit of customers and staff.
3. Ansetts BAe 146 modification program is so advanced that its fleet is not representative of the world's BAe 146s and therefore not appropriate for a study of the type proposed by ASHRAE.
Question 3
Ansett has demonstrated its complete commitment to corporate responsibility in this matter in ways unmatched by any other operator in Australia or overseas.
. Ansett has proactively liaised with CASA and BASI on the issue.

. Ansett aircraft modifications include engine and auxiliary power unit enhancements to prevent oil leaking into the air conditioning system and modifications to the air conditioning system to improve airflow in the cabin.
. Ansett has rigorously collected and analysed data and can produce overwhelming medical evidence to confirm the safety of their aircraft fleet for crew and passengers.
. Ansett will naturally continue to comply with all regulatory requirements.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
