I would have thought that anybody who could be pressured to take action in that regard would have been that person on the opposition's payroll. Yet gutlessness or ineffectiveness has meant that the Liberal Party has not acted in that area.

I do not know whether people are aware of what One Nation stands for in local government elections. It appears from an article of 5 August in the Sydney Morning Herald that there was a barney between the national and state executives and Mrs Hanson about whether to run candidates in the local government elections in New South Wales. Eventually Mrs Hanson must have been overruled by the other two members of the triumvirate because they are running in a number of crucial areas in New South Wales. One of the things that their guru, Mr David Oldfield, has pledged to doâand he is now a member of the New South Wales upper houseâwhen and if they get control or access to power in these local government areas is to, firstly, kill off the sorry books and, secondly, end multiculturalism at the local government level. The Liberal Party is going ahead and endorsing those actions by refusing to disendorse the Liberal candidates in the Sutherland election.

In the council election of Dubbo, the former National Party minister and member for Dubbo, Mr Gerry Peacocke, is running as an Independent with a number of other similarly minded Independents. Once again, this former coalition leader is directing his preferences to One Nation, saying that there is no connection with any other actions by the coalition. I do not believe it. I believe these actions are isolated, but they are connected. We saw yesterday in the Senate the actions of the coalition when we were called upon to vote on the vacancy on the competition committee. We know from the results that 40 people voted for Senator Brown and 27 people voted for Senator Harris. We in the Labor Party caucused and said that we were going to vote for Senator Brown because of what One Nation stands for. Where did those other 27 votes come from? They came from the Liberal side and the National Party side. They are supporting One Nation.

talk.start.para: âWhat does Senator Brown stand for?

âI will repeat for you what One Nation stand for. They stand for killing off the sorry books and ending multiculturalism at the local government level. That is what they stand for; that is what they are running on. That is what your coalition partners, those geniuses in New South Wales, are supporting. What the coalition did yesterday by supporting Senator Harris was, once again, one of those connected yet isolated incidents where the coalition are implicitly starting to develop their relationship with One Nation. What I say to people who might be listening, and to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that, as a member of the Senate, I am very worried about this development. I thought we had this agreement between the two parties, but I have just mentioned three instances when it has broken down. Over the next period we will see the coalition cosy up more and more to One Nation. We will see its policies starting to develop the One Nation agenda. We know what the One Nation agenda is. It seeks to exploit people's fears and prejudices. It seeks to make scapegoats of Asians, Aborigines and migrants. My fear is that, by their actions in the last few days and by the gutlessness of the New South Wales coalition, we will see the breakdown of this agreement and that will lead to further division in this country rather than unity.

âTonight we heard two very eloquent first speeches by Senator Aden Ridgeway and Senator Brett Mason. I thought they both defined very eloquently the many challenges facing our indigenous communities. I would like to raise one of those challenges in particular. Indigenous family violence is a topic which is seldom discussed in the community, yet its effects on families are horrific. Over the parliamentary break, I travelled to Darwin and Tennant Creek to meet some of the very courageous men and women who are helping to lead the fight against destructive family violence in their own communities. Some communities describe it as `Kosovo in our own backyard'.

speech.para: At the outset I congratulate ATSIC on the decision they have made to allocate increased funding to this absolutely crucial area. It used to be said that domestic violence was a women's issue, and I never quite understood why. But now it is much more correctly defined as a family issue. There are various forms of indigenous family violence, including violence against the aged. Sadly, family violence is now spanning generations and, in some cases, children raised in this environment accept it as part of life.

Recently at a roundtable I conducted in Port Augusta with indigenous women, I heard some quite horrific stories of family violence. Thank goodness indigenous communities themselves have decided that it is time to make fundamental change. The women that I met told me that it is the children who have sparked this change of direction. These women say that a healthy family and healthy children are fundamental to a strong cultural environment. I have heard the stories about the dreaded `thirsty Thursday' and the need for women and children to make themselves scarce to avoid the violence that can accompany payday. I visited communities that are now dry as a result of a decision made by the community itself, where a sign proudly proclaiming `This is an alcohol-free zone' is attached to every fence along those streets.

In Tennant Creek two very special women, Heather and Valda, proudly showed me how their night patrol ensures that children are returned to responsible adult supervision and that men and women who need help are taken to safe houses. Interestingly enough, since these two very brave women have been working on the patrol, the number of women needing emergency refuge care in the town of Tennant Creek has dropped significantly.

I also saw the respect with which these two women are treated in the community by police and business leaders. There is no doubt that this valuable service, together with sensible alcohol practices, is resulting in a dramatic improvement in community violence around the town of Tennant Creek. The men and women I met have come to understand that, as they say, `one drunk in a house of 10 sober people can destroy an entire household'. This government has grabbed this difficult issue and is working with those communities to ensure that they are strengthened by safe drinking practices.

Another enduring memory of the effectiveness of these programs comes from Darwin and a night patrol made up of a group of very special culturally sensitive men and women who know just how to handle some very tense and particularly volatile situations in that community. I found it quite unforgettable to see that, just behind the bright lights of the Darwin casino, there were men and women who very much appreciated and needed the safety offered by this night patrol taking them to a centre for a shower, a hot meal, clean clothes and a safe place to sleep.

I was very privileged to travel with the night patrols in Tennant Creek and also in Darwin, and I would particularly like to thank those people who made those trips possible for me. Many of the issues that we talked about during those dark hours, driving around those streets, were discussed quite openly at a very important forum recently held in Brisbane to discuss indigenous family violence. It was convened by Senator Herron, and I was privileged to attend as an observer at his invitation. A range of community representatives from all over Australia shared suggestions on ways to tackle this very difficult issue. As one participant said so simply, `Every broken life diminishes the nation.' I was interested to learn that, for many communities, enhancing the role of grandmothers is one of the very important foundations on which to tackle this issue and that effective night patrols are also an answer to much of the family violence which previously dominated many of the more remote communities.

So, instead ofâas Senator Aden Ridgeway so eloquently put it tonightâjust throwing money at this very sensitive issue, our government, through Minister John Herron in particular, has reset the priorities, and ATSIC has also recognised that this special problem needs special funding. It will be reducing its multimillion-dollar travel and public information budgets so that $1 million can be put aside this year to fund programs to tackle indigenous family violence.

In fact, ATSIC could do well to take note of very successful programs that are now being developed in the Northern Territory by the Aboriginal Family Violence Strategy, with valuable input from a very special woman, Eileen Cummings. The program is entitled `Family Violence is not the Aboriginal Way'. This strategy approaches the issue in a wide variety of ways: in the schools, in the prisons and in the communities. It uses material pre pared by indigenous men and women to show that there is another, safer way.

I pay tribute to all the quietly spoken and very courageous men and women who, in a practical and no nonsense way, are turning around what in many cases has been a generational family issue. As one speaker at the forum said to me, `Grog has been the black man's psychiatrist.' But now they are coming to realise that it does not have to be that way, and this government is here to help them. I commend these courageous men and women and the challenges they are taking on; I wish them every success.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to the 18 recommendations presented to the Government by the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force chaired by Mr Max Moore-Wilton:
(1) Which recommendations, by number, were based in whole or in part on recommendations of the report prepared by the now retired Air Vice-Marshal (AVM) Alan Heggen.

(2) For those based in whole or in part on recommendations of AVM Heggen: (a) what was the recommendation made by the report; and (b) what was the finding or findings of the report supporting the recommendation.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (2) As indicated in paragraph 2 of the task force report, all of AVM Heggen's key recommendations have been incorporated into the recommendations of the task force, except in relation to extending REEFREP radar coverage in the Torres Strait. The reasons for not incorporating the REEFREP recommendation are set out in paragraph 26 of the task force report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) audit report no. 32 of 1997-98, The Management of Boat People:
(1) Did the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force consider the report.
(2)Does recommendation no. 1 of this report state that a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) should be signed between Coastwatch and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA).
(3) Is it the case that DIMA continues to oppose the negotiation of an MOU with Coastwatch.

(4) Did the task force consider recommendation no. 1; if so: (a) why did the task force not recommend that DIMA follow the advice of ANAO; and (b) in what regard was ANAO mistaken in proposing an MOU as a means to improve the efficiency of surveillance operations against boats carrying illegal immigrants.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I am advised the following:
(1) Yes.
(2) Recommendation 1 states that an MOU should be developed between DIMA and Coastwatch incorporating a performance agreement setting out targets, indicators and respective responsibilities.

(3) The task force proposed that the additional funding provided for enhanced aerial surveillance be covered by a service provider agreement between DIMA and Coastwatch. Service provider agreements currently being developed as a result of that proposal would serve a broadly similar purpose to the MOU proposed in the ANAO report.

(4) The government believes the measures being adopted as a result of the work of the Coastal Surveillance Task Force, particularly the service provider agreements being developed between DIMA and Coastwatch, are consistent with the objectives underlying the recommendations of the ANAO report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Information Oversight Committee (IOC) to be established under recommendation 1 of the Coastal Surveillance Task Force:
(1) What are the agencies to be represented on the IOC.
(2) Is the focus of the IOC to be strategic or operational.
(3) What role will the constituent agencies play in deciding the program of the IOC.
(4) Which agency, or agencies, has the responsibility for: (a) determining the objectives of the IOC's intelligence program; (b) its annual work program; and (c) the evaluation of its performance.
(5) Will processes be available to allow Coastwatch to direct the IOC's intelligence programs to support operations planned or under way.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Office of National Assessments (chair); Australian Customs Service, including Coastwatch; Australian Federal Police; Department of Defence; Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and relevant intelligence agencies.
(2) The focus of the IOC will be strategic. Coastwatch will continue to manage operational intelligence.

(3)â(5) ONA will have prime responsibility for, and will take a leadership role in, the operation of the IOC. Constituent agencies will contribute as appropriate. There will be a level of liaison between ONA and Coastwatch appropriate to the strategic focus of the IOC.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to recommendation 6 of the 18 recommendations presented to the Government by the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force:

(1) (a) Will the $2 million in assistance, proposed for the control of potential illegal immigrants transiting Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, be a new appropriation or is it to be diverted from funds in assistance programs already approved; and (b) have the governments of Indonesia and Papua New Guinea been consulted on this recommendation; if so, what was their response.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) New appropriation; (b) The Task Force Secretariat briefed representatives from the Embassy of Indonesia and the High Commission of Papua New Guinea on 30 June 1999 on the task force's recommendations. The representatives expressed their interest in liaising further with Australian officials.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to recommendation 13 of the 18 recommendations presented to the Government by the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force:
(1) For what reasons did the task force recommend that the position of Director General Coastwatch be filled by a seconded Australian Defence Force (ADF) officer.
(2) What is to be the term of appointment of the officer seconded to the position.
(3) What criteria have been developed to identify ADF officers suitable for the position.
(4) What are to be the roles of additional ADF personnel seconded to Coastwatch.
(5) Did the task force assess the effects of various levels of seconded ADF personnel on the functioning of the Australian Customs Service chain of command.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) To help broaden the range of professional skills within Coastwatch and to improve coordination between Coastwatch and the Australian Defence Force.
(2) The term of appointment is expected to be two years.
(3) The criteria include strong personal leadership skills, strong interpersonal relations skills and extensive professional background in maritime operations and surveillance.
(4)â(5) The need for additional ADF personnel to be seconded to Coastwatch and the roles of such personnel are to be examined by the Director-General Coastwatch.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: Did the Coastal Surveillance Task Force assess the claims of the Department of Defence, as reported by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on 15 April 1999, that the Jindalee Operational Radar Network (JORN) will be of use in detecting boats which might be carrying illegal immigrants; if so: (a) did the task force determine the suitability of the presently planned search arcs of the JORN for meeting the requirements of recommendation 11; and (b) what recommendations did it make to the Department of Defence on this matter.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The task force found that the Department of Defence's Jindalee Operational Radar Network (JORN) already provides some limited information. Although JORN is not optimised for surface vessels, when completed in late 2001 it will be able to make a contribution to better detection.

(b) The task force was of the view that the expiry of the two major Coastwatch surveillance contracts in 2004 offers an opportunity for Coastwatch further to review the effectiveness of new technologies, including JORN. In deciding whether to renew the contracts, Coastwatch should carefully examine the capacity of emerging technologies to partly replace manned aerial surveillance and the contribution that could be made by the Department of Defence through mobile land-based radar operations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Coastal Surveillance Task Force assess the requirements for liaison between Coastwatch and: (a) the Australian Fisheries Management Authority; (b) the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; (c) the Australian Federal Police; (d) the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority; and (e) Environment Australia.
(2) For each of the above agencies, what are the current liaison arrangements with Coastwatch.
(3)What was the assessment of the task force as to the effectiveness of these arrangements.
(4) What proportion of aerial surveillance hours and 1998-2000 Coastwatch appropriations are devoted to: (a) illegal immigration control; and (b) other Coastwatch functions.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The primary focus of the Coastal Surveillance Task Force was on improving prevention of illegal boat arrivals. Liaison between Coastwatch and the agencies referred to was obviously an important element in the task force's considerations. The AFP Commissioner was a member of the task force.

(2) Each of the above agencies participates in a monthly meeting of Coastwatch's Operations and Program Advisory Committee which reviews Coastwatch operations. Coastwatch planning and operational staff are in daily contact with client agencies in relation to surveillance and response activities across the range of client tasking.
(3)Agencies generally were satisfied with their current liaison with Coastwatch and would not wish to see the level of liaison diminished.

(4) Coastwatch flights are multi-tasked, with each flight seeking to detect activity that may suggest offences against a variety of Australian legislation including the Customs Act and the Migration Act. For that reason no differentiation has been made either in hours or appropriations between the various Coastwatch functions.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation Inquiry by Defence Force Directorate of Flying Safety
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1231)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister of Defence, upon notice, 5 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Defence Force Directorate of Flying Safety (DFS) conducted an inquiry into an air safety incident between an Air Force P-3C Orion and a civilian aircraft that occurred during the search and rescue exercise to assist sailors in the 1998 Sydney to Hobart yacht race.
(2) (a) When did the incident occur; (b) when was the incident reported to DFS; and (c) when did DFS complete its investigation.
(3) (a) What were the findings of the DFS investigation into the above incident; and (b) what action resulted from the findings of the investigations.
(4) Can a copy be provided of the DFS report of its investigation into the above incident.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Directorate of Flying Safety and Australian Defence Force (DFS-ADF) and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) are jointly investigating an incident involving a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) P-3C Orion and a civilian aircraft while both were engaged in the search for missing sailors and yachts participating in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race. DFS-ADF has prime carriage of the investigation with support from BASI.
(2) (a) The incident occurred at approximately 0900 Eastern Daylight Saving Time on 28 December 1998.
(b) The incident was reported to DFS-ADF by telephone and message on 4 January 1999.
(c) The investigation is continuing. A joint DFS-ADF/BASI report will be released on completion of the investigation.
(3) (a) Significant factors in the incident and recommendations for preventative action will be published in the joint DFS-ADF/BASI report.
(b) The DFS-ADF/BASI report has not yet been completed.
(4) A copy of the joint DFS-ADF/BASI report will be forwarded to Senator O'Brien when it is complete.
